text: Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Metastatic prostate cancer with right ureteral stricture  Procedure:  1. Right antegrade nephrostogram and percutaneous nephroureterostomy exchange.   Findings:  1. Right antegrade nephrostogram demonstrates decompressed renal pelvis with PCN U tube in correct positioning 2. Newly placed 10.2 French X 24 cm PCN-U is appropriately positioned with the proximal loop in the renal pelvis and distal loop in the urinary bladder.  Impression:  Uneventful image-guided exchange of Right 10.2 French 24 cm percutaneous nephroureterostomy tube.   Plan:   Patient will be due for routine exchange in roughly 3 months.   Technique:  With the patient in prone position, the right flank were prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. A scout radiograph was obtained.   Contrast was injected through the existing nephrostomy/nephroureterostomy tube and imaging of the collecting was system performed. A 0.035" Glidewire advantage wire was placed through the tube and the tube removed over the wire and discarded. A new, 8-French x 22 cm nephroureterostomy tube was advanced over the wire under fluoroscopic guidance. The wire was removed and the proximal loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location.  The catheter was sutured to the flank and placed to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.    The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications.  Procedural Personnel Attending(s): [HCW] Fellow(s):     Resident(s): [HCW] Advanced practice provider(s): None  Complications: No immediate complications.  Contrast: 20 mL Omnipaque  Fluoroscopy time: 1.6 minutes Fluoroscopy dose:  1.66 mGy  Conscious Sedation:  Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by nurse present during the entire procedure. Patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Administered by the specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for a total of 40 minutes (Total intra service time).  Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  Medications: Versed 1 mg IV. Fentanyl 50 mcg IV.   Antibiotics: Rocephin, 2 g IV  Blood loss:  Less than 10 ml  Checklist:	Informed consent was obtained discussing the risks, benefits and alternatives to the planned procedure.  Pre-sedation H&P was performed and sedation consent obtained. The patient’s name, medical record number, date of birth, allergies, procedure being performed including site and pertinent laboratory values were reviewed and confirmed with the technologist, nurse and patient.  These requirements including the Time Out were met prior to initiating the procedure.       Janice Newsome, MD, was present for the key and critical portions of the procedure and associated imaging guidance.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Acute myeloid leukemia  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance 3.	Right internal jugular small bore central line removal   Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating in the right atrium 3.	The small bore central line was removed in its entirety en bloc  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance. 2.	Successful removal of small bore central line en bloc  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 and continuous 4-0 subcuticular absorbable sutures.  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with  Dermabond.   The sutures around the small bore central line were cut and the catheter removed. Hemostasis was achieved using manual pressure in the neck.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication.   Procedural Personnel Attending(s): Dr. Judy W. Gichoya Fellow(s): None  Resident(s): None Advanced practice provider(s): None  Complications: No immediate complications.  Contrast: 0 mL Omnipaque  Fluoroscopy time: 1.4 minutes Fluoroscopy dose:  2.62 mGy  Conscious Sedation:  Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by nurse present during the entire procedure. Patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Administered by the specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for a total of 60 minutes (Total intra service time).  Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  Medications: Versed 1.5 mg IV. Fentanyl 75 mcg IV.      Antibiotics: None  Blood loss:  Less than 10 ml  Checklist:	Informed consent was obtained discussing the risks, benefits and alternatives to the planned procedure.  Pre-sedation H&P was performed and sedation consent obtained. The patient’s name, medical record number, date of birth, allergies, procedure being performed including site and pertinent laboratory values were reviewed and confirmed with the technologist, nurse and patient.  These requirements including the Time Out were met prior to initiating the procedure.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  This is a 76-year-old man with multiple medical problems, including vascular dementia, stroke with right hemiparesis, hypertension, prostate cancer, and aspiration with acute respiratory failure with worsening metabolic encephalopathy who was admitted to the hospital on [DATE] and transferred to the ICU on [DATE] with a GI bleed/hematochezia and hypotension. CT angiogram showed a bleed in the rectum. Thrombocytopenia (18,000 platelets) precluded colonoscopy and he was taken to the IR suite for embolization under anesthesia.  Procedures: Ultrasound and fluoroscopy-guided  peritoneal catheter placement Ultrasound and fluoroscopy-guided pericardial drain placement  Findings: The CT angiogram from 10:40 AM was reviewed  1. The cardiac silhouette is enlarged. The left hemidiaphragm is elevated. There is contrast in the left colon. Monitor leads are in place. A CO2 monitor is in the distal esophagus. 2. Ultrasound confirms pericardial fluid. It appears to be of similar amount to that seen on the CT from several hours earlier. 3. The initial 8 French catheter placed aspirated frank blood. Contrast injection confirmed this to be in the peritoneal cavity. Several 100 mL bloody fluid were aspirated and a sample was sent to the lab. 4. Contrast injection of the second catheter confirms pericardial location. 5. Pericardial fluid returned clear yellow. 6. An 8 French pigtail catheter is adequately positioned and the pericardium. A total of 80 mL clear fluid were aspirated.  Impression:   Critically ill patient who experienced cardiac arrest prior to the visceral arteriography initiation.  An 8 French peritoneal catheter was placed, aspirating bloody fluid.  An 8 French pericardial drain aspirated 80 mL clear yellow fluid.    Technique:  The patient was brought to the IR suite in critical condition.  A left radial art line was in place. Since a radial approach was warranted due to severe thrombocytopenia, the left radial art line was exchanged for a 5 French slender technology sheath. Attention was redirected to placement of an material line on the right for monitoring.  Prior to procedure initiation, the patient experienced cardiac arrest. ROSC was achieved. The patient was responding poorly to resuscitative efforts. Due to the presence of ultrasonographic pericardial fluid and poor left ventricular volume, the decision was made to place a pericardial drain.  The anterior chest wall was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. A 21-gauge needle was advanced toward the pericardial fluid under direct ultrasound guidance. Initially, the wire coursed caudal. The catheter was placed and found to be in the peritoneal cavity. Several 100 mL grossly bloody fluid were aspirated.  From a different window, a longer 21-gauge needle was used to access the pericardial space. Ultrasound images confirmed location. Fluid returned was clear yellow. A 0.018 inch wire was placed. The needle was exchanged for a transitional dilator. The smaller wire was replaced with a short Amplatz wire. Contrast injection confirmed pericardial location. The transitional dilator was exchanged for an 8 French pigtail catheter.  The retention loop of this catheter was formed in the pericardium. 80 mL clear yellow fluid were removed.  The patient was found to be in refractory shock and in spite of blood product administration, pericardial drain placement, and massive pressor support, he could not be successfully resuscitated. The procedure was aborted.   Procedural Personnel Attending(s): Gail Peters Fellow(s): None Resident(s): None Advanced practice provider(s): None  Complications: No immediate complications.  Contrast: 20 mL Omnipaque  Fluoroscopy time: 2.4 minutes Fluoroscopy dose:  45 mGy  Conscious Sedation: The procedure was performed with anesthesiology present with the patient intubated.  Antibiotics: None  Blood loss:  Less than 10 ml  Checklist:	Informed consent was obtained discussing the risks, benefits and alternatives to the planned procedure.  Pre-sedation H&P was performed and sedation consent obtained. The patient’s name, medical record number, date of birth, allergies, procedure being performed including site and pertinent laboratory values were reviewed and confirmed with the technologist, nurse and patient.  These requirements including the Time Out were met prior to initiating the procedure.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Cerebral palsy, developmental delay, gastroparesis with prior dislodged gastrojejunostomy tube and replaced with gastrostomy tube.  Procedure:   1.	Exchange of 18 French gastrostomy tube for a low profile gastrojejunostomy tube.       Findings:   Scout image demonstrates a gastrostomy tube with balloon projecting within the plane of the left upper quadrant. There is diffuse gaseous distention.  1.	The existing tube is confirmed to be within the gastric lumen.   2.	The new low profile tube is appropriately positioned with the distal aspect of the tube terminating in jejunal loops within the plane of the right upper quadrant. Findings are suggestive of small bowel malrotation.  Impression:   1.	Successful exchange for an 18 French 3.5 cm low profile gastrojejunostomy tube with tip in jejunum.  2.	Jejunal loops are noted to be in the plane of the right upper quadrant indicative of small bowel malrotation.  Treatment Plan:    It is OK to use the tube immediately.      Routine check and change recommended in 6 months.  Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).    A scout image was obtained over the abdomen with findings detailed above.  Contrast was injected through the existing gastrostomy tube to confirm position as detailed above. Next, a stiff Glidewire was cannulated through the gastrostomy tube and seen coiling within the gastric lumen. The balloon was deflated gastrostomy tube was removed over the wire however during the exchange wire access was lost. Next, a 5 French Kumpe catheter and stiff Glidewire were used to navigate under fluoroscopic guidance through the subcutaneous tract and into the gastric lumen which was confirmed with contrast injection.  The Kumpe catheter and stiff Glidewire were used to navigate through the pylorus and opacify jejunal loops noted to be within the right upper quadrant. A stoma measuring device was used to measure the stoma length and was noted to be an approximately 3.5 cm. A  22 French peel-away sheath was advanced into the gastric lumen. Through this a new 18 French by 3.5 cm gastrojejunostomy tube was advanced over the wire through the peel-away sheath. Its tip was placed in the proximal jejunum. The bulb was inflated with approximately 10 mL of 10% contrast mixture. The wire was removed and contrast injection confirmed appropriate positioning of the gastric and jejunal side ports. The disc was cinched.        Procedural Personnel Attending(s): Dr. Steven Citron Fellow(s): Dr. Rameez Rehman Resident(s): None Advanced practice provider(s): None  Complications: No immediate complications.  Contrast: 70 mL      Fluoroscopy time: 4.4 minutes Fluoroscopy dose:  8.3 mGy  Conscious Sedation: Sedation was provided via general anesthesia. For further details please refer to the anesthesia record.  Medications: For further details please refer to the anesthesia record.  Antibiotics: None  Blood loss:  Less than 10 ml  Checklist:	Informed consent was obtained discussing the risks, benefits and alternatives to the planned procedure.  Pre-sedation H&P was performed and sedation consent obtained. The patient’s name, medical record number, date of birth, allergies, procedure being performed including site and pertinent laboratory values were reviewed and confirmed with the technologist, nurse and patient.  These requirements including the Time Out were met prior to initiating the procedure.       Steven Citron, MD, was present for the key and critical portions of the procedure and associated imaging guidance.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]C.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Pancreatic mass with biliary obstruction.   Sequence of events so far:  1. [DATE]      Common bile duct access lost during endoscopic stent exchange   2. [DATE]      PTC with 12 French right internal/external biliary drain placement under GA 3. [DATE]      Biliary drain malpositioned with peritoneal loop. The catheter 12 French was exchanged with moderate sedation 4. [DATE]      A covered stent was placed in the common hepatic and common bile duct under sedation, requiring a large amount of narcotic with poor pain control 5. [DATE]      Today the patient returns for cholangiography for possible drain removal under general anesthesia   PROCEDURE: Catheter cholangiogram and internal/external drain replacement     FINDINGS: Comparison is made to a prior study dated [DATE]. Images from [DATE] and [DATE] were also reviewed..  1.  The scout radiograph shows the internal/external biliary drain appearing appropriately positioned. There is no leakage at the flank. 2 covered stents are visualized in the extrahepatic bile ducts. 2.  Sheath cholangiogram shows narrowing of the common hepatic duct above the central extent of the stent. The bile ducts are decompressed. 3.  There is extrinsic compression by mass from the left toward the right, narrowing the cephalad portion of the common hepatic duct just beyond the biliary confluence. This is seen as a filling defect with injection at the confluence. 4. The hepatic parenchymal tract is mature. 5. There is ongoing fistulous communication of the mass with the duodenum. 6. The newly placed 12 French right internal/external biliary drain is appropriately positioned. The cope loop was removed to prevent suture entanglement with the stents should further exchanges be required.   IMPRESSION:  1.  Interval progression of tumor with extrinsic compression of the common hepatic duct near the biliary confluence. 2.  Uneventful image guided replacement of an internal/external biliary catheter as described. 3. This patient will be catheter dependent from this point forward.   PLAN: 1.  Routine maintenance in 12 weeks. 2.  The patient was asked to go to the emergency room for lower extremity swelling. He declined and states he would rather go to the emergency room near his home in [HOSPITAL].   TECHNIQUE:    The existing catheter and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.    A 0.035" glidewire was negotiated through the catheter into the small bowel.  The catheter was removed over the wire and a short 8 French sheath placed. Sheath injection evaluated the biliary tree. Proximal tumor extension was identified with extrinsic compression just beyond the hilum.  A DSA run showed a patent stent with some irregularity and prompt flow into the duodenum. A 5F catheter was placed adjacent to the glide to better delineate the cephalad portion of the common hepatic duct.  A tractogram was performed on sheath withdrawal.  A 12 French internal/external biliary drain with extended sideholes (no standard catheter available) was modified by removing the retention suture and placed over the wire.  Contrast was injected to confirm tube position.  The tube was capped.  The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 Ethilon.  The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications and was discharged still asleep into the care of anesthesiology for transfer to the PACU.   Procedural Personnel Attending(s): Gail Peters Fellow(s): None Resident(s): None Advanced practice provider(s): None  Complications: No immediate complications.  Contrast: 40 mL Omnipaque  Fluoroscopy time: 4.3 minutes Fluoroscopy dose:  150 mGy  Conscious Sedation: The procedure was performed under general anesthesia with intubation   Antibiotics: 2 g IV Rocephin  Blood loss:  Less than 10 ml  Checklist:	Informed consent was obtained discussing the risks, benefits and alternatives to the planned procedure.  Pre-sedation H&P was performed and sedation consent obtained. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]C.[ID].1  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Right breast cellulitis s/p right breast reconstruction with DIEP flap and XRT; postop seroma at flap donor site (left lower quadrant)  Procedure:   US-guided drainage of right breast  collection US guided aspiration of left lower quadrant fluid collection  Findings:   1. Real-time US images through the right chest wall demonstrate appropriate percutaneous drainage. 2. Real-time US images through the left lower quadrant demonstrate appropriate fluid pocket for aspiration  Impression:   Technically successful US-guided drainage of right breast/chest wall fluid collection, aspiration of left lower quadrant flap donor site.  Treatment Plan:   1. Flush drain with 20 cc saline q8h as inpatient and 20 cc saline q24h as outpatient. 2. When drainage falls to below 10 cc/day (excluding flushes) for three consecutive days, please obtain repeat cross-sectional imaging and/or contact IR for possible removal.  Technique:  Target: right chest wall  Imaging: US Drain: 8 Fr APD/Mermaid Drainage: 70 mL serosanguinous fluid aspirated during procedure Microbiology: Sample sent  Target: left lower quadrant Imaging: US Drain: 5F catheter used to aspirate, then removed Drainage: 40 mL serous fluid aspirated during procedure Microbiology: Sample sent  A superficial skin entry site was selected based on available imaging and the overlying skin entry site was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier to target the above collection. The skin surface was anesthetized with 1-2% lidocaine. Using continuous real-time grayscale and/or color doppler ultrasound guidance, a needle was introduced into the target site and imaging guidance confirmed adequate positioning. The access device was utilized with an 0.035" wire to introduce the drainage catheter listed above following any necessary serial dilatation. Ultrasound images confirmed appropriate positioning within the target structure. The catheter was secured to the skin surface using nonabsorbable suture material and dressed in typical fashion. Any samples not sent to laboratory for analysis were discarded. The patient tolerated the procedure and was sent to the recovery area for monitoring. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Metastatic breast cancer with chylous ascites. This patient had a prior Pleurx catheter which was removed for infection on [DATE]. She is requiring paracentesis every few days.   Procedure: PleurX tunneled peritoneal drainage catheter placement with ultrasound and fluoro with large volume paracentesis         Findings:  Removal images from [DATE] and abdominal CT scan from [DATE] were reviewed  1. There is moderate chylous ascites. 2. The peritoneal catheter is positioned appropriately, coursing from the right into the left lower quadrant. 3. Total volume removed was 3.75 L.   Impression:  Recurrent chylous ascites.  Uneventful image guided placement of 15 French multi sidehole PleurX intraperitoneal  catheter to facilitate frequent large volume paracentesis.  3.75 liters clear yellow fluid were removed without incident.   Technique:    The anterior abdominal wall was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Ultrasonographic evaluation was carried out, and an appropriate entry site identified in the right mid abdomen. Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the peritoneal space was accessed with an 18-gauge sheathed needle. Hilar fluid was returned. Needle entry was documented, and images transferred to PACS.  An Amplatz wire was placed through the catheter and directed toward the left paracolic gutter. The skin tract was dilated and a large peel-away sheath placed.    The soft tissues cephalad and medial to the sheath entry site were anesthetized with 2% lidocaine with epinephrine. A dermatotomy was created, and the PleurX catheter was pulled through the tunnel with the tunneling device. The cuff was positioned in the midportion of the 8 cm tunnel.  The intraperitoneal wire and dilator were removed, and the catheter was placed through the peel-away. It was positioned using fluoroscopy. The peel-away was removed.  The peritoneal puncture site was closed with a deep 3-0 absorbable suture and Dermabond.   2-0 Ethilon suture was placed at the tunnel exit site to secure the catheter.  A sterile dressing was applied.  Subsequently, large volume paracentesis was performed through the newly placed catheter. A total of 3.75 liters clear yellow fluid were removed.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient was discharged in satisfactory condition.   Procedural Personnel Attending(s): Gail Peters Fellow(s): None Resident(s): None Advanced practice provider(s): None  Complications: No immediate complications.  Contrast: 0 mL Omnipaque  Fluoroscopy time: 0.8 minutes Fluoroscopy dose:  6 mGy  Conscious Sedation:  Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by nurse present during the entire procedure. Patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Ovarian Cancer  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution with epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 absorbable sutures and Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with  Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. CT right knee [DATE] identifies 3 persistent collections and 1 undrained collection.  Procedure:   Ultrasound and fluoroscopic guided drainage of Right knee fluid collection (1) Fluoroscopic guided drain evaluation and exchange of right knee fluid collections (3)  Findings:   1. Real-time ultrasound and intermittent fluoroscopic images through the right knee demonstrate appropriate percutaneous drainage. 2. Intermittent fluoroscopic images through the right knee demonstrate small residual collections.  Impression:   Technically successful ultrasound and fluoroscopic drain placement into 1 right knee fluid collection, and a drain upsize into the persistent 3 right knee fluid collections.  Treatment Plan:   1.	Flush drain with 20 cc saline q24h as outpatient. 2.	Follow-up with plastic surgeon at scheduled appointment at end [DATE]. Determine if Incision & Drainage is planned. If not, discuss IR's intent to perform sclerotherapy as the collections will have been present for ~5 months and she has completed 3 drain placement/evaluations already without resolution. 3.	Return to IR in 6-8 weeks for percutaneous drain evaluation and Doxycycline sclerotherapy. Or, when drainage falls to below 10 cc/day (excluding flushes) for three consecutive days, please obtain repeat cross-sectional imaging and/or contact IR for possible removal.  Technique:  Target: Right knee abscesses  Imaging: US & Fluoroscopy Drain: 10 Fr APD x 3, 12 Fr APD x 1 Drainage: 20 mL serosanguinous fluid aspirated during procedure Microbiology: N/A  A superficial skin entry site was selected based on available imaging and the overlying skin entry site was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier to target the above collection.  Upper-lateral right knee collection: The skin surface was anesthetized with 1-2% lidocaine. Using realtime US imaging guidance, a needle was introduced into the target site, with imaging guidance confirming adequate positioning. The access device was utilized with an 0.035" wire to introduce the drainage catheter listed above following any necessary serial dilatation. Fluoroscopic images confirmed appropriate positioning within the target structure. The catheter was secured to the skin surface using nonabsorbable suture material and dressed in typical fashion. Any samples not sent to laboratory for analysis were discarded.   Lower-lateral right knee collection: The skin surface was anesthetized with 1-2% lidocaine. Using intermittent fluoroscopic imaging, the existing drain was injected with contrast to confirm appropriate position and estimate the size of residual collection. The suture was cut, drain retention mechanism release, and a wire advanced into the collection. Over the wire, existing 8 Fr APD was exchanged for a 10 Fr APD. Wire was removed and contrast and fluid contents aspirated. The catheter was secured to the skin surface using nonabsorbable suture material and dressed in typical fashion. Any samples not sent to laboratory for analysis were discarded.  Lower-medial right knee collection: The skin surface was anesthetized with 1-2% lidocaine. Using intermittent fluoroscopic imaging, the existing drain was injected with contrast to confirm appropriate position and estimate the size of residual collection. The suture was cut, drain retention mechanism release, and a wire advanced into the collection. Over the wire, existing 8 Fr APD was exchanged for a 10 Fr APD. Wire was removed and contrast and fluid contents aspirated. The catheter was secured to the skin surface using nonabsorbable suture material and dressed in typical fashion. Any samples not sent to laboratory for analysis were discarded.  Upper-medial right knee collection: The skin surface was anesthetized with 1-2% lidocaine. Using intermittent fluoroscopic imaging, the existing drain was injected with contrast to confirm appropriate position and estimate the size of residual collection. The suture was cut, drain retention mechanism release, and a wire advanced into the collection. Over the wire, existing 10 Fr APD was exchanged for a 12 Fr APD. Wire was removed and contrast and fluid contents aspirated. The catheter was secured to the skin surface using nonabsorbable suture material and dressed in typical fashion. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  EtOH cirrhosis s/p SLK with sustained AKI concerning for HRS.  Procedure:   Transjugular liver biopsy with pressure measurements  Findings:   1.	The right hepatic vein is normal in caliber and appearance. 2.	The biopsy specimen appeared adequate. 3.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. Needle entry was documented. 4.	Pressures:  a. Wedged hepatic pressure: 16 mm Hg b. Free hepatic pressure: 14 mm Hg c. Corrected Sinusoidal Pressure: 2 mm Hg  d. Right atrial: 7 mm Hg e. Infra-hepatic IVC: 18 mm Hg f. Post-anastomotic IVC: 18 mm Hg     Impression:   Successful image guided transjugular liver biopsy. Corrected sinusoidal pressure of 2 mm Hg.    Treatment Plan:  Follow up pathology results.  Technique:   The procedure, options, and risks were reviewed with patient, including bleeding, infection, and pneumothorax. A time out was performed before initiating the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). Patient sedation was performed, as detailed below.  The right neck was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle with permanent reporting and recording. An image documenting vein patency and needle entry was stored and transferred to PACS. A 9 French sheath was placed at the neck.  An angled catheter was used to select the right hepatic vein and hepatic venography performed using nonionic contrast. Free and wedged hepatic pressures were obtained using the diagnostic catheter.  A 0.035” wire was placed in the hepatic vein and the 7 French Cook biopsy cannula was advanced over the wire. The wire was removed, and 3 passes made with the 18 gauge coaxial needle.  The specimen was placed in formalin and delivered to the laboratory.  The cannula and sheath were removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. No immediate complication occurred, and the patient was discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  acute myelocytic leukemia  Procedure:  1. Fluoroscopic guided exchange of tunneled small bore central line to a large bore central line (Line removal and new line placed - via exchange over wire)  Findings:  1. Scout image demonstrates existing right internal jugular vein tunneled small bore central line with tip positioned in the right atrium. 2. Newly exchanged right internal jugular tunneled large bore central line (trifusion) is appropriately positioned with the tip in the right atrium.   Impression:  Uneventful image guided wire exchange of a right internal jugular vein tunneled small bore central line to a right internal jugular tunneled large bore central line (trifusion)   Plan:  Catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:  The right chest wall and area immediately around the existing tunneled catheter was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier.  Using local anesthetic, the tract was anesthetized. Suture securing line cut and removed. A V18 wire was passed down existing small bore tunneled line and down the inferior vena cava. Imaging stored onto PACS. The catheter was then pulled with gentle traction until it was completely removed over the wire. The smaller dilator in the line trifusion kit was passed over the V18 wire. A amplatz wire was then passed through the dilator after the V18 was removed and passed down the inferior vena cava. The small dilator was removed over the wire and the larger peel-away sheath was then passed over the wire into position. A new triple lumen trifusion catheter was advanced over the wire until the tip was positioned appropriately and the cuff positioned within the tunnel.   Nonabsorbable suture was placed at the catheter tunnel exit site. An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and heparinized per protocol. The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient was discharged in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  CNS lymphoma  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the right atrium.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a  15.5 French, 19 cm (tip-to-cuff), tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   1. Routine catheter care. 2. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissues overlying the vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the dialysis catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS.  Procedural Personnel Attending(s): Dr. J. David Prologo Advanced practice provider(s): Ian McMillan, PA-C  Complications: No immediate complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  End-stage renal disease requiring hemodialysis access. Known central venous stenoses.  Procedure:   1.	Bilateral upper extremity to central venography 2.	Inferior vena cavagram 3.	US evaluation of the right internal jugular vein 4.	Conversion of left femoral vein vascath to permcath  Findings:   1.	Occlusion of the bilateral brachiocephalic veins with sluggish flow towards the heart via collaterals. 2.	Patent IVC with large filling defects in the infrarenal IVC and bilateral common iliac veins corresponding to non-occlusive thrombosis demonstrated on recent cross-sectional imaging.  3.	Distal right IJ thrombus as also seen on recent cross-sectional imaging. 4.  Successful conversion of preexisting left groin vascath to 55cm permcath, terminating near the inferior cavoatrial junction.  Catheter is ready to use.  Impression:   1. Right internal jugular and iliocaval acute thromboses. 2. Bilateral brachiocephalic venous occlusion, with extensive collaterals. 3. Successful placement of left common femoral venous tunneled hemodialysis catheter.  Treatment Plan:   1. Routine catheter care. 2. The catheter is ready for immediate use. 3. Therapeutic anticoagulation recommended.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  Bilateral upper extremity central venography was performed by contrast injection into previously placed peripheral intravenous catheters under fluoroscopy with findings as detailed above. The right internal jugular vein was evaluated with ultrasound and permanent images stored to PACS.  The skin and subcutaneous tissues surrounding the indwelling left common femoral venous nontunneled catheter were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic. Contrast was injected into this catheter and images were stored. After local anesthetic was injected, a new 55 cm PermCath was tunneled through the skin of the thigh towards the venotomy site. A 0.035 inch stiff Amplatz wire was advanced through the indwelling catheter, and the indwelling catheter was removed over the wire. A peel-away sheath was advanced over the wire. The new catheter was advanced through the peel-away sheath into the inferior vena cava.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.  The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by nurse present during the entire procedure. Patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 34 years Female who presents for diagnostic cerebral angiography following coil embolization of an anterior communicating artery aneurysm   PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 20 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Left Internal Carotid Artery  ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for the duration of the procedure as outlined above (Total intra service time, 20 ). Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Versed 1 mg IV Fentanyl 50 mcg IV Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter  Cardiva Vascade Visipaque-270 contrast material (40 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the left internal carotid artery for better delineation of the underlying angioarchitecture. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Vascade followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Prior angiogram.  FINDINGS:  LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: The previously coil embolized anterior communicating artery embolism demonstrate minimal residual filling at the base measuring 2 mm x 0.6 mm. The bilateral ACAs fill from the left A1 segment. Flash filling of the right A1 and M1 segments is noted with a patent right A1 segment.  The ICA and its segments are normal course and caliber. The MCA and its branches are normal course and caliber. There is normal cortical venous drainage. No other aneurysms are identified.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated minimal residual filling at the base of the previously coil embolized anterior communicating artery aneurysm measuring 2 mm x 0.6mm.   COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: There is minimal residual filling of the previously coil embolized anterior communicating artery aneurysm measuring 2 mm x 0.6mm. This aneurysm fills predominantly from the left A1 segment of the ACA. The bilateral ACA territories continue to fill from the left A1 segment.  Feras Akbik, MD, was present for the key and critical portions of the procedure and associated imaging guidance.

DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM, SOLUMBRA THROMBECTOMY  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 45 years year old Male who presents with an acute stroke syndrome secondary to a right M1 occlusion.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 30 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW], was the attending physician. He supervised the entire procedure. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right Internal Carotid Artery Right common femoral artery  ANESTHESIA: MAC. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart.  MEDICATIONS:  Verapamil 5mg Lidocaine 10cc Ancef 2 g IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 6 French Pinnacle Terumo Sheath (as a transitional dilator) 8 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 8 French Walrus balloon guide catheter 0.035" Bentson Guidewire 0.035" Bentson Guidewire, exchange length 5 French Simmons 3 Glide catheter Asahi 018 microguidewire Trak 21 microcatheter RED 68 Aspiration Catheter Trevo NXT 4 x 41 Stentriever device  Mynx closure device Omnipaque-300 contrast (80 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient's family (medical proxy). Specifically, the risks of intracranial or systemic hemorrhage, cerebral infarction, distal emboli, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, device malfunction, groin hematoma, arterial dissection/laceration, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite, intubated, and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; an 8 French sheath was introduced into the right common femoral artery. The 8 French balloon guide-catheter and diagnostic catheter were introduced into the right common carotid artery as a system. A roadmap angiogram was completed of the common carotid artery to visualize the carotid bifurcation. The diagnostic catheter was then used to select the internal carotid artery over the guidewire. The balloon guide catheter was then advanced into the cervical internal carotid artery over the wire and diagnostic catheter. The wire and diagnostic catheter were then removed and the balloon guide was connected to a continual heparinized saline flush. Digital angiograms were performed centered over the head.   The initial TICI score was 2b secondary to a subocclusive clot in the proximal right M1 segment. Note was made of cervical ICA vasospasm . 5 mg intra-arterial verapamil was infused and a repeat run demonstrated improvement in the previously noted vasospasm.  A triaxial system of the aspiration catheter, microcatheter, and microguidewire were advanced into the internal carotid artery over roadmap guidance. The Trak 21 microcatheter and Asahi 018 microwire were then advanced through the aspiration catheter past the MCA occlusion. A microrun confirmed intravascular placement.  The aspiration catheter was then tracked to the face of the clot. The wire was removed from the microcatheter and replaced with the Trevo NXT 4 x 41 stentriever device.  The stentriever was deployed under fluoroscopy and the allowed to set in the clot for 5 minutes. The microcatheter was removed so that that the stentriever was "naked" in the aspiration catheter. The balloon on the guide catheter was then inflated. The stentriever was then removed under continuous aspiration using a 60cc syringe. Thrombus was  identified within the stentriever device.  The balloon on the guide was deflated and a cerebral angiogram was performed through the guide catheter. Recanalization of the MCA was achieved with revascularization of the distal territory consistent with TICI 2c.  An angiogram of the right common femoral artery was obtained; the artery was deemed not appropriate for use of the 8 French Angio-Seal closure device. The sheath was removed and hemostasis obtained by deployment of the Mynx closure device. A Tegaderm was then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: Non-invasive imaging, same day  FINDINGS:  RIGHT  INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: A subocclusive clot is noted in the proximal M1 segment of the right MCA consistent with TICI 2b.  Note is made of severe spasm in the cervical ICA just distal to the catheter tip.  RIGHT  INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (post verapamil infusion): A subocclusive clot is noted in the proximal M1 segment of the right MCA consistent with TICI 2b.  There is markedly improvement of the spasm noted in the cervical ICA.  RIGHT  INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-THROMBECTOMY, 1st pass): Reperfusion has been reestablished consistent with TICI 2c. There is no residual narrowing of the right M1 segment.  RIGHT FEMORAL ARTERY: No abnormalities are detected. The catheter enters just distal to the bifurcation is therefore not suitable for an intravascular closure device.  COMPLICATIONS: none immediate.  IMPRESSION:  1. There is a subocclusive clot in the proximal right M1 segment of the MCA consistent with TICI 2b.  2. Status-post 1 pass thrombectomy with resultant TICI 2c. There is no residual narrowing of the right M1 segment.

The Trak 21 microcatheter and Asahi 018 microwire were then advanced through the aspiration catheter past the ACA occlusion for a fourth pass. The aspiration catheter was then tracked to the face of the clot under continuous aspiration. The wire was removed from the microcatheter and replaced with the Trevo NXT 4 x 41 stentriever device.  The stentriever was deployed under fluoroscopy and the allowed to set in the clot for 5 minutes. The microcatheter was removed so that that the stentriever was "naked" in the aspiration catheter. The balloon on the guide catheter was then inflated. The stentriever was then removed under continuous aspiration using a 60cc syringe. Thrombus was  identified within the stentriever device and the aspirate.  The balloon on the guide was deflated and a cerebral angiogram was performed through the guide catheter. There is recanalization of the ACA territory with reperfusion of the ACA territory consistent with TICI 3.   An angiogram of the right common femoral artery was obtained; the artery was deemed appropriate for use of a closure device. The sheath was removed and hemostasis obtained by deployment of the Mynx closure device. A Tegaderm was then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: Non-invasive imaging, same day  FINDINGS:  RIGHT  COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CERVICAL: There is slow filling of the right internal carotid artery consistent with occlusion distal to the cervical ICA. The ECA branches opacify normally.  RIGHT  INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: A ICA terminus occlusion is identified consistent with TICI 0.  RIGHT  INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-THROMBECTOMY, 1st pass):  There remains slow filling of the right internal carotid artery consistent with occlusion of the supraclinoid ICA. This is consistent with TICI 0.   RIGHT  INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-THROMBECTOMY, 2nd pass):  There is occlusion of the M1 segment of the MCA with subocclusive clot in the A1 segment of the ACA. This is consistent with TICI 1.   RIGHT  INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-THROMBECTOMY, 3rd pass): Reperfusion has been reestablished in the MCA territory consistent with TICI 2c. Note is made of an occlusion of the a2-3 junction of the right ACA.   RIGHT  TOTAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-THROMBECTOMY, 4th pass): Reperfusion has been reestablished in the right ACA territory consistent with TICI 3. There is TICI 2c reperfusion of the right hemisphere.  RIGHT FEMORAL ARTERY: No abnormalities are detected. This vessel is suitable for use of the Mynx closure device.  COMPLICATIONS: none immediate.  IMPRESSION:  1. Right ICA occlusion with initial occlusion consistent with TICI 0.  2. Status-post 4 pass thrombectomy with resultant TICI 2c.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Retroperitoneal hematoma with hemorrhagic shock.  PROCEDURE:     1.	US-guided right common femoral artery access. 2.	Aortogram  3.	L3 lumbar angioembolization 4.	Selective angiography of the left T10, T11, and T12 intercostal arteries, the left L4 lumbar artery, the left external and internal iliac arteries, the left deep circumflex artery. 5.	Post-embolization L3 angiography and completion aortogram 6.	Right common femoral artery angiogram and closure  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized using base catheter and microcatheter/microwire combination and angiograms performed:  Abdominal aorta: Generalized arterial vasospasm. Small foci of active hemorrhage arising from distal branches of the left L3 lumbar artery. T10 intercostal artery: No active hemorrhage. T11 intercostal artery: No active hemorrhage. T12 intercostal artery: No active hemorrhage.  L1 lumbar artery: Diminutive and not opacified on aortography. Unable to be catheterized L2 lumbar artery: Diminutive and not opacified on aortography. Unable to be catheterized L3 lumbar artery: Persistent focus of active extravasation along the distal and branch  L4 lumbar artery: No active hemorrhage  Left external iliac artery: No active hemorrhage Lateral proximal deep circumflex artery: No active hemorrhage Tiny branch external iliac extending to the left lower abdomen and flank: No active hemorrhage  Left internal iliac artery: No active hemorrhage  Post-embolization L3 artery angiography: Cessation of extravasation.  Transcatheter embolization: Embolic: Obsidio conformable embolic Details (type/size/volume/number): 0.10 mL  IMPRESSION:   Active extravasation noted arising from the distal L3 lumbar artery in the region of the left flank correlating with patient's known retroperitoneal hematoma.  Technically successful embolization of the left L3 lumbar artery.   TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Continued clinical and laboratory monitoring recommended. Please contact interventional radiology if there is a change in clinical status. 2. Routine post-angiography groin cares ordered. Maintain RLE straight for 2 hours  3. Continue resuscitation, correction of coagulopathy    TECHNIQUE: With the patient in the supine position, the groin was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. Following standard prepping and draping, the right common femoral artery was punctured using a needle. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. An 0.035" wire was advanced into the aorta. A vascular sheath was placed over the wire into the common femoral artery. A side flush was started.  A 5-Fr Omni Flush diagnostic catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the abdominal aorta. Aortogram was performed as detailed above. Next, the Omni Flush was exchanged for a 5 French Mickelson catheter. The catheter was used to catheterize the vessels described above. Angiograms were performed. A 2.8 F Progreat microcatheter system and Asahi Meister microwire was used to catheterize distal vessels, as described above. Specific vessels catheterized.  Once the catheter was in adequate position, utilization was performed using Obsidio conformable embolic. Approximately 0.10 ml was introduced into the microcatheter and flushed using contrast to deliver the embolic to the desired location. Postembolization angiography was performed as detailed above.  Next, the Mickelson catheter was exchanged for the Omni Flush catheter. Using a 0.035'' wire the catheter was placed at the iliac bifurcation and used to advance a wire to the contralateral left external iliac artery. The Omni flush catheter was exchanged for a 5 French Cobra C2 glide catheter and advanced into the left external iliac artery. Angiography was performed as detailed above. Once again the microcatheter system was used to subselect vessels as detailed above. The Cobra C2 glide was then used to catheterize the left internal iliac artery. Angiography was performed as detailed above.  Finally, completion aortography was performed which demonstrates cessation of the previously noted active extravasation. No new areas of active extravasation are noted along the left flank.  All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. Hemostasis was achieved using vascular closure device, Angio-Seal. The site was dressed in usual fashion.  The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM WITH INTRA-ARTERIAL VERAPAMIL INFUSION FOR TREATMENT OF VASOSPASM  CLINICAL INDICATION: 75-year-old female with Hunt-Hess 1 subarachnoid hemorrhage from a ruptured V4 segment artery aneurysm with vasospasm on the basis of noninvasive imaging and trans-cranial doppler.  PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram. Intra-arterial verapamil infusion in bilateral ICA.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 90minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician. He supervised the entire procedure. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Left vertebral artery Right internal carotid artery Left internal carotid artery  VESSELS TREATED: Right internal carotid artery Left internal carotid artery  ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal anesthesia administered by anesthesia staff.   MEDICATIONS:  Heparin 5000 units IV 30 mg IA verapamil  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter Visipaque 270 contrast material (100 cc) Mynx closure device  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient's medical proxy. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, balloon rupture, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, heart block, hypotension, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery. A 5 French sheath was introduced into the right common femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously after sheath placement; additional boluses of heparin were administered at one-hour intervals. Using fluoroscopic guidance, the above vessels was selectively catheterized with the 5 French diagnostic catheter. Digital angiograms were performed centered over the head. In the right and left internal carotid artery 15 mg of intra-arterial verapamil were administered using a pulse spray technique over 10 minutes on each side.   A follow-up control angiogram was performed in each of the right and left internal carotid arteries after infusion.  Following completion of the procedure, hemostasis was achieved by application of a Mynx closure device. A Tegaderm was then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: Cerebral angiogram dated 12/29/2023.  FINDINGS: LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: The previously treated giant vertebral artery segment aneurysm demonstrates mild compaction of coils when compared to angiogram from yesterday with filling at the base of the aneurysm.. The flow diverting stent is patent and without change in caliber throughout its length in the vertebral artery when compared to immediate post placement runs. There is no significant vasospasm noted in the posterior circulation. Reflux of contrast into the  contralateral vertebral artery was not achieved. The origin of left PICA is normal.  LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (PRE-SPASMOLYSIS): There is moderate vasospasm noted throughout the MCA territory and severe vasospasm located in the left ACA territory both proximally and distally. There is delay of filling of the ACA territory as a result of this vasospasm.  LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (IA SPASMOLYSIS): There is improvement of vasospasm throughout the MCA territory and is now mild in appearance. The ACA territory demonstrates some improvement and is now moderate in severity distally. There is no longer delayed filling of the ACA territory.  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (PRE-SPASMOLYSIS): There is mild to moderate vasospasm noted throughout the MCA territory and severe vasospasm located in the right ACA territory both proximally and distally. There is delay of filling of the ACA territory as a result of this vasospasm.  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (IA SPASMOLYSIS): No significant residual vasospasm noted in the right MCA territory. The ACA territory demonstrates some improvement and is now moderate in severity distally. There is no longer delayed filling of the ACA territory.  COMPLICATIONS: none immediate.  IMPRESSION:  1. The previously treated left vertebral artery segment aneurysm demonstrates mild compaction of coils when compared to angiogram from yesterday. The flow diverting stent in the vertebral artery is patent and unchanged in appearance.  2. There is severe vasospasm noted in the bilateral ACA territories which improved to moderate in the distal segments following IA verapamil and moderate vasospasm in the MCA territories which improved to mild following spasmolysis. Following intra-arterial spasmolysis, there was no longer delay in filling of the ACA territories bilaterally.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Small bowel syndrome central venous access needed.   Procedure:   1.	Tunneled central venous double-lumen Hickman catheter placement   2.	Left tunneled central venous line removal  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the Hickman catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the right atrium. 3.	Post surgical changes of thoracic and cervical rod and screw fixation 4.	Successful left tunneled central venous line removal  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a tunneled Hickman catheter.       Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care.  The catheter is ready for immediate use.        Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS.  A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The catheter was tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.   The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]  Clinical Indication:  Left ureteroileal anastomotic stricture managed with a modified left nephroureterostomy tube.   Procedure:  1. Left antegrade nephrostogram and percutaneous nephroureterostomy exchange.   Findings:  1. Left antegrade nephrostogram demonstrates unchanged distal ureteral stricture. 2. Newly placed modified PCNU is appropriately positioned with the proximal loop in the renal pelvis and catheter tip in the distal ureter.  Catheter:  10.2-Fr Cook nephroureterostomy tube, modified with the distal end cut  Impression:  Uneventful image-guided exchange of Left percutaneous nephroureterostomy tube.   Plan:   Patient will be due for routine exchange in 10-12 weeks.   Technique:  With the patient in prone position, the left flank was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. A scout radiograph was obtained.   Contrast was injected through the existing nephroureterostomy tube and imaging of the collecting was system performed. A 0.035" wire was placed through the tube and the tube removed over the wire and discarded. A 5 French Kumpe catheter was negotiated over the wire into the distal ureter. After the wire was straightened out, a new, 10.2-French Cook modified nephroureterostomy tube was advanced over the wire under fluoroscopic guidance. The wire was removed and the proximal loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location.  The catheter was sutured to the flank and placed to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.    The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Multiple myeloma  Procedure:  1. Ultrasound and Fluoroscopic guided placement of a tunneled, cuffed central venous catheter  Findings:  1. The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and normal. Vein patency and needle entry were stored to PACS. 2. The newly placed catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating in the right atrium.  Impression:   Uneventful image guided placement of right internal jugular vein tunneled Trifusion catheter as described.  Technique:  The right neck and chest region was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. The region was ultrasonographically evaluated.  Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle.  An image documenting vein patency and needle entry was saved and stored to PACS.   A 0.018” wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a 5 French transitional dilator. A 0.035” wire was advanced through the dilator and negotiated into the IVC.  The skin tract was dilated and a 13 French dilator peel-away combination placed over the wire.  The soft tissues caudal and lateral to the sheath entry site were anesthetized with lidocaine with epinephrine. A dermatotomy was made and a tunneling tool brought from the dermatotomy to the venotomy. The catheter was brought through the tunnel.  During suspended respiration, the catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy. The peel-away was removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression.  The venotomy was closed with Dermabond and Steri-Strips applied. A single Prolene suture was placed at the catheter tunnel exit site. An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and heparinized per protocol. The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient was discharged in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Patient with ampullary cancer requiring IV chemotherapy  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (ISP)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Sedation the anesthesia. Please refer to anesthesia notes for medication.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with     Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication.
