Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Lymphoma  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard 20 cm port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 2-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Right ovarian cancer  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance on the right chest  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 2-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with a single subcuticular stitch and Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Pre-sedation H&P was performed and sedation consent obtained. The patient’s name, medical record number, date of birth, allergies, procedure being performed including site and pertinent laboratory values were reviewed and confirmed with the technologist, nurse and patient.  These requirements including the Time Out were met prior to initiating the procedure.  I, Simon Jian NP did the above procedure with Patrick Francois PA-C. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Myelodysplastic syndrome  Procedure:  1. Ultrasound and Fluoroscopic guided placement of a tunneled, cuffed central venous catheter  Findings:  1. The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and normal. Vein patency and needle entry were stored to PACS. 2. The newly placed catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating in the right atrium.  Impression:   Uneventful image guided placement of right internal jugular vein tunneled Trifusion catheter as described.  Technique:  The right neck and chest region was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. The region was ultrasonographically evaluated.  Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle.  An image documenting vein patency and needle entry was saved and stored to PACS.   A 0.018” wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a 5 French transitional dilator. A 0.035” wire was advanced through the dilator and negotiated into the IVC.  The skin tract was dilated and a 13 French dilator peel-away combination placed over the wire.  The soft tissues caudal and lateral to the sheath entry site were anesthetized with lidocaine with epinephrine. A dermatotomy was made and a tunneling tool brought from the dermatotomy to the venotomy. The catheter was brought through the tunnel.  During suspended respiration, the catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy. The peel-away was removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression.  The venotomy was closed with Dermabond and Steri-Strips applied. A single Prolene suture was placed at the catheter tunnel exit site. An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and heparinized per protocol. The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient was discharged in satisfactory condition. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by nurse present during the entire procedure. Patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  End-stage renal disease on hemodialysis  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled dialysis catheter placement 2.	Removal of left internal jugular Vas-Cath  Findings:   1.	Left internal jugular vein with Vas-Cath in place with tip near the cavoatrial junction 2.	After placement of the new tunneled dialysis catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated exchange of nontunneled dialysis catheter for new 15.5 French 23 cm tip to cuff tunneled dialysis catheter   Treatment Plan:   1. Routine catheter care. 2. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below.  The skin and subcutaneous tissues surrounding the existing left IJ nontunneled dialysis catheter were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic. A 0.035 wire was placed through the Vas-Cath port and directed into the IVC under fluoroscopic guidance. The Vas-Cath was removed over the wire and replaced with a dilator. Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the dialysis catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   At this point during the procedure the patient's oxygen saturation began to decrease into the 60s and 70s. A code met was called and patient was reversed using the Narcan. After reversal and treatment with nonrebreather patient's oxygen saturation returned to 98%. Patient was an alert and oriented moving extremities.  After the code met was called, the area was reprepped. The catheter was tested however neither port was able to be aspirated. Catheter was exchanged over the wire for a new catheter which functioned properly.  The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Breast cancer status post bilateral mastectomy. Patient with recurrent chylous leak. Prior lymphangiogram without thoracic duct leak, no embolization performed. Patient underwent thorascopic thoracic duct ligation, with persistent chylous leak.  PROCEDURE:   1. Lymphangiogram. 2. Accessory thoracic duct embolization. 3. Direct cisterna chyle leak embolization.   FINDINGS:  1. No thoracic duct opacification, in keeping with prior surgical ligation.  2. Access into an accessory thoracic duct, without evidence of leak. Successfully embolized with glue (1:1 glue:Lipiodol, 2 cc).  3. Direct access into leak originating at this cisterna chyle, successfully embolized with glue (1:2 glue:Lipiodol, 3 cc).  IMPRESSION:   Technically successful accessory thoracic duct and cisterna chyle glue embolization.  TREATMENT PLAN:  Monitor chest tube drain output, and follow-up with cardiothoracic surgery.   TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the bilateral groins and wide abdomen was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier.   A scout radiograph demonstrated lipiodol staining in the bilateral groins from prior lymphangiogram.  Ultrasound evaluation of bilateral groins demonstrated very few scant, normal-appearing lymph nodes. A small lymph node in the right groin was accessed using a 25-gauge spinal needle, and lipiodol was injected. Under fluoroscopic visualization, lipiodol was seen transiting up the iliac chain. Evaluation of the left groin without any appropriate lymph node target lipiodol injection.  A lymph node in the left iliac chain was then targeted under direct fluoroscopic guidance and accessed using a 21-gauge Chiba needle. More lipiodol was injected, and transitted up the iliac chain to the abdominal lymph nodes.  Intermittent fluoroscopy demonstrated transit of the lipiodol through the abdominal lymphatic network to cisterna chyle, however no lipiodol was seen transiting up into the chest. The cisterna chyle, was then directly accessed using a 21-gauge Chiba needle under fluoroscopic guidance. Lipiodol injection demonstrated mild lipiodol opacification and transit up into the chest however no dominant intrathoracic lymphatic duct or definite intrathoracic leak could be identified. A V18 wire was able to be navigated into an accessory thoracic duct into the chest. Cone beam CT confirmed positioning of the wire in this duct, without evidence of leak. The thoracic duct (known location from prior lymphangiogram), could not be identified, in keeping with the patient's known history of thoracic duct ligation.  Attention was then turned to the patient's neck, where we attempted to access the venolymphatic junction deep to the left internal jugular vein, however multiple attempts were unsuccessful, and these attempts were aborted.  We then reviewed the images obtained point extensively, that even before early injections of the cisterna chyle, lipiodol appeared to be leaking towards the right upper quadrant/right lower chest. Cone beam CT was then performed, and lipiodol was confirmed in the right pleural space, indicating that this truly was the site of leak.   The 21-gauge Chiba needle was then used to access a lymph node one vertebral body lower than the cisterna chyle, and glue was injected to this lymph node (with some retrograde flow noted down the abdominal lymphatic chain). The needle was then used to access the confirmed leak near its neck adjacent to the cisterna chyle. More glue was injected, under direct fluoroscopic evaluation, and lipiodol was seen within the chest tube.  At the end of the procedure all needles and wires were removed from the patient's body. The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Impression:  Uneventful image-guided exchange of bilateral percutaneous nephroureterostomy tubes.   Plan:   Patient will be due for routine exchange in 10-12 weeks. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Right obstructive uropathy with ureteral stone. Failed cystoscopic double-J ureteral stent placement  Procedure:   1. US guided calyceal access   2. Right antegrade pyelography  3. Right percutaneous nephroureteral catheter placement  Findings: Abdominal CT from [DATE] was reviewed  1. There is moderate to severe right hydroureteronephrosis with parenchymal thinning and obstruction in the distal ureter near the lower SI joint. 2. Hydronephrosis and needle entry images into the posterior interpolar calyx were stored to PACS. Urine returned was cloudy. 3. A urine sample was sent for analysis 4. The renal pelvis is bifid. 5. An 8.5 French by 28 cm nephroureteral catheter has its proximal cope loop in the lower pole moiety of the bifid renal pelvis and its distal cope loop in the urinary bladder.   Impression:   Uneventful image guided placement of an 8.5 French by 28 cm right nephroureteral catheter as described.  Treatment plan:  The patient will follow-up with urology. Follow-up catheter maintenance was scheduled for 8 weeks.   Technique:  Right:  1% lidocaine was used as local anesthetic. Under ultrasound guidance a 21-gauge micropuncture needle was introduced into the posterior interpolar calyx.  An 0.018" wire was passed through the needle into the renal pelvis. The needle was removed and a 6 French coaxial dilator was placed over the wire.   Antegrade pyelography was performed.    A 4 French angled glide catheter and Glidewire were placed coaxially through the transitional dilator and access to the bladder achieved. Contrast injection confirmed location. An Amplatz wire was placed and coiled in the bladder.   The dilator was removed and an 8.5 French by 28 cm  nephroureteral catheter was advanced over the wire. The distal cope loop was formed in the urinary bladder and the proximal Cope loop  was formed within the renal pelvis.  The catheter was anchored to the skin utilizing 2-0 Ethilon and attached to gravity drainage. Later, in the ARU, the tube was capped at the request of the referring urologist.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite  still asleep discharged into the care of anesthesiology for transfer to the PACU. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Liver transplant rejection; need for Plex therapy  Procedure:   1.	Non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates near cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a 14 French,  20 cm, non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. An image was saved and stored to PACS.  A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Patient with prostate cancer requiring IV chemotherapy  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen MedComp port (dignity)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Medcomp power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with     Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL][ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Thrombocytopenia  Procedure:   1.	US-guided right IJ venous access 2.	Inferior vena cava filter placement  Findings:  Inferior vena cavogram: Single renal veins bilaterally without aberrant anatomy (no duplicated IVC or accessory renal veins). The IVC is normal in caliber and without caval thrombus. Filter placed: Bard Denali Inferior vena cavogram post-deployment: Appropriate positioning below the renal veins without significant filter tilt. No evidence of thrombosis, perforation, or other complication.  Impression:   1.  Uneventful image guided placement of an infrarenal IVC filter.  Treatment Plan:  1. Patient will f/u in IR clinic for consultation for possible filter removal.  Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained.  The specific risks of bleeding, infection, pulmonary embolism, filter maldeployment, and filter migration were detailed and accepted. Written informed consent was obtained. The patient was assessed for conscious sedation and found to be an adequate candidate. A dedicated nurse monitored heart rate, blood pressure, and oxygen saturation throughout the procedure. Patient was brought to the procedure suite and a time out was performed prior to procedure initiation. The right neck was prepped and draped in sterile fashion.   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the access site were infiltrated with lidocaine for local anesthetic. Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency. Under continuous ultrasound guidance, with permanent recording and reporting, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018" wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire. Through the micropuncture introducer set, an 0.035" wire was advanced into the IVC under fluoroscopic guidance. A sheath was placed at the access site, as detailed. A catheter and/or sheath combination was advanced into the IVC and cavography was then performed, with findings detailed above.  Under direct fluoroscopic guidance, the filter described above was positioned and deployed through the delivery system. A repeat venogram was performed, documenting appropriate positioning.  All instruments and devices were removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. No immediate complication occurred, and the patient was discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Patient with pancreatic cancer requiring IV chemotherapy  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen MedComp port (dignity)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Medcomp power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). Procedure was performed with anesthesia. Please refer to anesthesia notes for details. The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with     Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Gallbladder mass with central biliary obstruction  Procedure:   1.	Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram 2.	Placement of percutaneous transhepatic internal/external biliary drain 3.	Gallbladder mass biopsy under ultrasound guidance   Findings:   1.	Occlusion of the common bile duct secondary to extrinsic compression from known mass.  Impression:   1. Technically successful percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography and drainage catheter placement. 2. Technically successful gallbladder mass biopsy under ultrasound guidance.    Plan:  1.	Open to bag drainage for 24 hours.  2.	Routine drain exchange in 8 weeks.  Technique:   The anterior abdominal wall and bilateral flanks were prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier.  An appropriate skin entry site was identified using fluoroscopy and ultrasound, and anesthetized with local.  Under fluoroscopic guidance, a 22G Chiba needle was advanced into the liver.  A bile duct was entered and the biliary system was opacified with contrast. Cholangiographic images were obtained.  Two-stick technique: A suitable duct for drain placement was then identified on the right. Under direct sonographic guidance, a right duct was accessed with a second 22 gauge Chiba needle.  A 0.018" wire was passed centrally, and the needle exchanged for a nonvascular access catheter. The inner stiffener, dilator, and 0.018" wire were removed and contrast was injected to confirm location.  A 0.035" glidewire and 4 French angled catheter were negotiated into the small bowel. The glidewire was removed and contrast was injected to confirm location. A 0.035" Amplatz wire was placed through the catheter, and the catheter subsequently removed.   Drain placement: Finally, an 10.2 French     internal-external biliary drain was placed over the wire. The anchor/loop was formed and locked. Attention was paid that side holes were positioned within the biliary system. Contrast was injected to confirm location. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 suture material and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  Contrast was injected through the existing biliary drainage catheter and cholangiographic images obtained.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition.  Biopsy: Under ultrasound guidance an introduced was advanced into the gallbladder mass. Via the introducer an 18G mission biopsy needle was advanced into the gallbladder mass and biopsy was obtained. Samples were sent in formalin. Gel foam tract embolization was performed via the introducer. The needle was removed and sterile dressing applied. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Metastatic disease of unknown primary with new bilateral hydronephrosis  Procedure:   1.	Left nephrostogram and nephrostomy tube placement      Findings:  Comparison is made to a previous exam dated [DATE] US.  1.	Ultrasound exam of the kidneys was performed demonstrating moderate left hydronephrosis. The right renal cortex was atrophic and poorly visualized. No right hydronephrosis was seen.  2.	Left antegrade nephrostogram was performed with moderate hydronephrosis and no passage of contrast urinary bladder. 3.	Nephrostomy tube appropriately positioned within the left renal pelvis.  Catheter(s):  8.5 F     nephrostomy tube  Impression:   1.	Uneventful ultrasound and fluroscopic-guided placement of a left nephrostomy tube as described above.      Treatment Plan:   Patient should return for routine check and change in 8-12 weeks.        Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written informed consent was obtained.  A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation.  The soft tissues overlying the access site were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Ultrasound was utilized to identify an appropriate access site. Static ultrasound image was obtained and stored to PACS for reference purposes. Subsequently, under fluoroscopic and real-time concurrent ultrasound guidance, access was obtained into a posterior, inferior calyx using a 21 ga needle and a triaxial sheath system (Neff). Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. A wire was advanced centrally. Serial dilation was accomplished over the wire. The wire and inner dilator were removed. Non-ionic contrast was injected into the collecting system and images of the antegrade pyelogram were obtained and stored to PACS.  An 0.035” wire was advanced through the existing access. A nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Dysphasia, GJ retracted   Procedure:   1.	GJ-tube replacement.       Findings:   1.	The existing tube is appropriately positioned   2.	The new tube is appropriately positioned with the distal aspect of the tube terminating in the portion of the jejunum  Impression:   1.	Successful replacement of 14 French  x 2.5 cm (stoma) x 45 cm AMT gastrojejunostomy tube with tip in jejunum.      Treatment Plan:    It is OK to use the tube immediately. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  End-stage renal disease, difficult intravenous access  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled central venous catheter placement   Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the tunneled catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a double lumen power-injectable, 5 Fr, 22 cm, tunneled non-cuffed central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care.  The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a peel-away sheath set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture peel-away sheath set, the wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: Previously ruptured anterior communicating artery aneurysm, status post coil embolization x2  PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 30 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Left internal carotid artery  ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for a total of 30 minutes (Total intra service time).  Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.035" Bentson guidewire 5 French Boston [VENDOR] sheath 5 French Simmons 3 Glide catheter  Mynx Closure Device Visipaque-270 contrast material (40 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the [VENDOR]mons catheter in the left internal carotid artery for better delineation of the anterior communicating artery aneurysm. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Mynx closure device followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Cerebral angiogram dated March 20, 2023.  FINDINGS:  LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a coil mass at the site of the previously treated anterior communicating artery aneurysm. There is a small amount of coil compaction and residual aneurysm neck, better described on the 3-D angiogram below. This appears grossly stable compared to prior. There is no focal stenosis or early draining vein  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated recurrent anterior communicating artery aneurysm neck, measuring approximately 2.6 x 3.7 millimeters (dome-to-neck by neck).  COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: 1. There is a recurrent anterior communicating artery aneurysm neck, measuring approximately 2.6 x 3.7 millimeters (dome to neck by neck). This appears stable compared to prior angiogram based on the 2-D images.     Frank C Tong, MD, was present for the key and critical portions of the procedure and associated imaging guidance.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  ESRD  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the right atrium.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a  15.5 French, 23 cm (tip-to-cuff), tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   1. Routine catheter care. 2. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissues overlying the vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the dialysis catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Left breast cancer  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen MedComp port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 2-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with a single subcuticular stitch and Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and locked per protocol. It was secured in place with Ethilon.  An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  Technique Drain:  Target: Left groin collection Imaging: US+CT Drain: 10.2 Fr Cook Drainage: 1-2 mL bloody fluid aspirated during procedure Microbiology: Sample sent  A superficial skin entry site was selected based on available imaging and the overlying skin entry site was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier to target the above collection. The skin surface was anesthetized with 1-2% lidocaine. Using continuous real-time grayscale and/or color doppler ultrasound guidance, a needle was introduced into the target site and imaging guidance confirmed adequate positioning. The access device was utilized with an 0.035" wire to introduce the drainage catheter listed above following any necessary serial dilatation. Ultrasound images confirmed appropriate positioning within the target structure. The catheter was secured to the skin surface using nonabsorbable suture material and dressed in typical fashion. Any samples not sent to laboratory for analysis were discarded. Given minimal output the drain was cut and removed.The patient tolerated the procedure and was sent to the recovery area for monitoring. Patient's Name: [PATIENT]  MRN: [ID] [DATE] 12:27 PM   IR CENTRAL PORT  Indications: Right breast cancer planned to start IV chemotherapy.  Request is made for port placement  Procedure: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and answering all questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site, allergies was performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned supine with the head turned to the left. The procedure is performed under continuous physiologic monitoring. The patient received intravenous conscious sedation using Versed 2.5 mg and fentanyl 125 mcg.  Also the patient received Ancef 2 g IV.  The left side of the lower neck and upper chest was prepped with Betadine followed by chlorhexidine and draped in a sterile fashion.  Following administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1% with epinephrine 8ml at the left side of the root of the neck, under ultrasound  guidance, access was obtained into the left internal jugular vein using a micropuncture device. A 0.018" guidewire was advanced under fluoroscopy into the vein centrally. Further administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1% with epinephrine 10 mL into the left infraclavicular region. A transverse 3.5  cm incision was performed and a pocket created inferior to the incision to accommodate the port using both sharp and blunt dissection. Through the infraclavicular incision, the port tubing 8 F was tunneled exiting at the root of the neck following a nick incision at the exit of the guidewire. The guidewire was upgraded to 0.035" guidewire that was advanced under fluoroscopy through the SVC into the IVC. A peel-away sheath was advanced over the guidewire. Following removal of the guidewire and the stiffener, the port tubing was advanced after trimming to a length of 23.7 cm. The sheath was peeled away and the line was buried in the subcutaneous tissues. The tip of the line is at the SVC/upper right atrium. The port was tested demonstrating easy aspiration and injection and was flushed with normal saline followed by hep saline as per protocol. The port was anchored in the subcutaneous tissues using nonabsorbable 2/0 interrupted stitches. The wound was irrigated. Hemostasis secured. The incision at the root of the neck was closed using Dermabond. The infraclavicular incision was closed using subcutaneous followed by subcuticular Vicryl 4/0 continuous stitches. Steri-Strips were applied followed by Sterile occlusive dressing. The patient tolerated to the procedure well. There were no intraprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to recovery in stable condition and eventually discharged. The port is ready to use. Please also refer to the Procedure note placed in the patient's EPIC chart on the date of the procedure.  Fluoroscopy time: 00:35.5 min.  Device implanted: 8F single lumen power port, LOT #REHW1854, REF #5608062.  Fellows: None. Residents: None.  IMPRESSION: 1. Uneventful ultrasound fluoroscopy guided placement of 8F Power  infusion port in the left internal jugular vein. The port is ready to use.  Voice recognition is used in generating this report.

DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 75 years Female past medical history of hypertension, who is found to have a right MCA aneurysm upon a vertical workup on MRI, who presents for diagnostic cerebral angiography.   PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 45 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW]. was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. [HCW] PhD was the resident. All actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right internal carotid artery Right external carotid artery Left internal carotid artery Left common carotid artery Left vertebral artery  Right innominate artery  ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for the duration of the procedure as outlined above (Total intra service time, 45 min ). Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Versed 1 mg IV Fentanyl 25 mcg IV Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 5 French Cordis vert catheter  Cardiva Vascade Visipaque contrast material (110 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the right internal carotid artery for better delineation of the underlying angioarchitecture. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Vascade followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: None.  FINDINGS: RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a large right MCA bifurcation aneurysm, better described on the 3-D angiogram below. There is no focal stenosis or early draining vein identified.   RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified.   LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The cervical and intracranial ICA, MCA, and ACA branches do not demonstrate any aneurysm or focal stenosis. The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the contralateral vertebral artery was not achieved. The origin of PICA is normal on the left.   RIGHT INNOMINATE ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm is identified arising from the right PICA. The previously described MCA bifurcation aneurysm is again visualized. No other new aneurysms are visualized. There is no focal stenosis or early draining vein.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated a 6.0 x 6.2 x 7.5 x 5.5 mm (transverse by transverse by dome to neck by neck) right MCA bifurcation aneurysm.   COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: 1. There is a 6.0 x 6.2 x 7.5 x 5.5 mm (transverse by transverse by dome to neck by neck) right MCA bifurcation aneurysm.   Charles M Cawley, MD, was present for the key and critical portions of the procedure and associated imaging guidance.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Cervical cancer with vesicovaginal fistula  Procedure:   1.	Bilateral nephrostogram(s) and nephrostomy tube replacement  Comparison: Previous exam [DATE] nephrostomy tube exchange  Findings:    1.	Existing nephrostomy tube on the left is retracted within a calyx. The right nephrostomy tube is appropriately positioned. 2.	Nephrostography demonstrates hydronephrosis without drainage into the urinary bladder.   Catheter: Left 8.5 French modified PCN U, right 10.2 French by 25 cm PCN  Impression:   1.	Bilateral image guided nephrostomy tube re-placement.  Treatment Plan:   Patient should return for routine check and change in 6-8 weeks.  Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written informed consent was obtained. A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation.  The existing catheter(s) and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Right: Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. A scout radiograph was obtained.  Non-ionic contrast was injected through the existing nephrostomy tube(s) and images of the collecting system obtained and stored to PACS.  An 0.035” wire was advanced through the nephrostomy tube. The tube was removed over the wire under direct fluoroscopic visualization. A new nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed appropriate location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  Left: Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. A scout radiograph was obtained.  Non-ionic contrast was injected through the existing nephrostomy tube(s) and images of the collecting system obtained and stored to PACS.  An 0.035” wire was advanced through the nephrostomy tube. The tube was removed over the wire under direct fluoroscopic visualization. Several attempts with different catheter types were made to perform the cope loop within the renal pelvis, however, the pelvis was too small/stenotic to accommodate the loop. The decision was made to place a modified PCN U given ability to form the loop within the pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed appropriate location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.   The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Left groin wound/fluid collection with need for long-term antibiotics  Procedure:   1.	Double lumen PICC placement using ultrasound and fluoroscopy     2.	US guided drainage of left groin fluid collection  Findings:   1.  Vein patency was documented by ultrasound and stored to PACS. 2.  The catheter tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.       3. Real-time US images through the left groin collection demonstrate appropriate percutaneous drainage.   Impression:   1.	Uneventful image guided placement of 5 French, 50 cm double-lumen PICC in the left upper extremity as described. The lumens flush and aspirate appropriately.       2.	Attempted drainage of a left groin fluid collection. The drainage catheter was aspirated and only scant viscous blood products were returned. The drain was subsequently removed.  Treatment Plan:   Catheter tip position is confirmed as above. It is OK to use this line.  Continue to monitor clinically. Can reattempt drainage if there is worsening of the left groin collection  Technique PICC:   The site was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).   Ultrasound evaluation of the left basilic vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS. Local anesthetic was used over the access site. Under ultrasound guidance, the left basilic vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS.    A 0.018" wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a dilator peel-away combination. The wire was used to determine catheter length, and a 5 French double-lumen PICC line cut to appropriate length. The tailored catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy.   The peel-away was removed, and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and locked per protocol. It was secured in place with Ethilon.  An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  Technique Drain:  Target: Left groin collection Imaging: US+CT Drain: 10.2 Fr Cook Drainage: 1-2 mL bloody fluid aspirated during procedure Microbiology: Sample sent  A superficial skin entry site was selected based on available imaging and the overlying skin entry site was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier to target the above collection. The skin surface was anesthetized with 1-2% lidocaine. Using continuous real-time grayscale and/or color doppler ultrasound guidance, a needle was introduced into the target site and imaging guidance confirmed adequate positioning. The access device was utilized with an 0.035" wire to introduce the drainage catheter listed above following any necessary serial dilatation. Ultrasound images confirmed appropriate positioning within the target structure. The catheter was secured to the skin surface using nonabsorbable suture material and dressed in typical fashion. Any samples not sent to laboratory for analysis were discarded. Given minimal output the drain was cut and removed.The patient tolerated the procedure and was sent to the recovery area for monitoring. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Pancreatic cancer  Procedure:   1.	Gastrostomy tube placement under fluoroscopic guidance.  Findings:   1.	The gastrostomy tube is in good position.  2.	Gentle hand injection of contrast material confirms positioning of the gastrostomy tube within the gastric lumen.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of 18 French MIC gastrostomy tube as above.  Treatment Plan:   The tube should be placed to gravity drainage and should not be used for 24 hours. 25 cc of water can be administered per hour. At 4 hours, if residuals are less than 30%, the patient can have tube feeds advanced starting at a half dose.   Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the mid abdomen were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.   Using fluoroscopic and ultrasonographic guidance, an appropriate puncture site was identified.  3 T-fasteners were placed adjacent to the planned tube access site. Positioning of the T-fasteners within the gastric lumen was confirmed by return of air and direct injection of contrast material.  Next, under fluoroscopic guidance, an 18-gauge needle was directed into the gastric lumen. Needle positioning within the gastric lumen was confirmed with aspiration of air as well as gentle hand injection of contrast material.  A wire was advance through the 18-gauge needle.  The 18-gauge needle was removed over a wire. Serial dilation was accomplished over the stiff wire. An 18 French Halyard G-tube was advanced over a wire in an antegrade fashion and advanced through the anterior abdominal wall. All wires and catheters were removed. The bulb was inflated with 10 mL of a 10% contrast mixture. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the gastric feeding tube within the gastric lumen. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained for reference purposes. The tube was flushed with saline. It was affixed to the anterior abdominal wall with a rubber flange. The patient tolerated the procedure well at time of procedure completion without complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Pelvic pain, right leg swelling, prior laparoscopy showing dilated pelvic collaterals   Procedure 1.	Right internal jugular vein access  2.	Right external and common iliac venogram 3.	Right common iliac IVUS  4.	Left external and common iliac venogram  5.	Left common iliac IVUS  6.	Left renal venogram  7.	Left renal vein IVUS  8.	Left ovarian vein venogram 9.	Left ovarian vein embolization with STS foam, coils, and Gelfoam. 10.	Postembolization left ovarian vein venography. 11.	Postembolization left renal venogram.  IVUS utilized during case  Impression: Right common and external iliac veins are patent without hemodynamically significant narrowing or pelvic collaterals.  Left common and external iliac veins are patent without hemodynamically significant narrowing or pelvic collaterals.  Left renal vein is patent without hemodynamically significant narrowing, mild gonadal vein reflux with valsalva.  Left ovarian venography confirms right vein is abnormally dilated with reflux into the pelvis with abnormally dilated left periuterine veins  Successful left ovarian vein embolization/sclerotherapy with STS foam, coils, and Gelfoam. Postembolization left renal venogram shows patent left renal vein without reflux into the left ovarian vein.  Findings: VENOGRAPHY: The following vessels were catheterized and diagnostic venography was performed:  RIGHT COMMON ILIAC VEIN: Venogram: Right common and external iliac veins are patent without stenosis. No abnormal pelvic collaterals.  IVUS utilize: Yes. No stenosis.  LEFT COMMON ILIAC VEIN: Venogram: Left common and external iliac veins are patent without stenosis. No abnormal pelvic collaterals.  IVUS utilized: Yes. No stenosis.  LEFT RENAL VEIN: Venogram: Left renal vein is patent without hemodynamically significant narrowing, mild gonadal vein reflux with valsalva.   IVUS utilized: Yes, no renal vein stenosis.  Left ovarian vein: Venogram: Ovarian vein mildly dilated up to 6 mm. Contrast flows caudally and pools in prominent pelvic collaterals.  INTERVENTION:  Embolization of the left ovarian vein Embolic: 6 cc STS foam Balt coils 4 mm x 35 cm, 3 mm x 20 cm, 3.5 mm x 30 cm 2 cc Gelfoam slurry  POST INTERVENTION: Venogram: No visualized pelvic collaterals to the left common iliac vein IVUS utilized: Yes. Patent stent with no stenosis of the common iliac vein.  Technique: Access site(s): Right Internal jugular vein  The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. The specific risks of bleeding, infection, and nontarget embolization were explained.  Written informed consent was obtained. A timeout was performed.  The patient was placed supine on the angiography table and the right neck prepped and draped in sterile fashion.   Under ultrasound guidance, the right jugular vein was accessed with a 21-gauge needle. Vein patency and needle entry were stored to PACS. A 0.018" wire was advanced, and the needle exchanged for a transitional dilator. An 0.035 wire was negotiated into the IVC. A short 8 French sheath was placed at the neck and flushed.  An angled catheter was used to select the right external iliac vein and venography and IVUS were performed with findings as above. Procedure was repeated for the left side.  An angled catheter was used in combination with a Glidewire to select the left renal vein. Left renal venography was performed with and without Valsalva with findings as above.  The angled catheter and Glidewire were used to selectively catheterize the left ovarian vein. Left ovarian venography was performed. A Rosen wire was placed, and the catheter removed over the wire. A long 6 French sheath was advanced to the midportion of the left ovarian vein. A 4 French Fogarty balloon was advanced over the wire. The balloon was inflated, and the volume of the pelvic veins estimated via contrast injection. The catheter was flushed and the veins were cleared.  A sclerosing solution with 3:2:1 Air:STS:Lipiodol was then infused through the Fogarty under direct fluoroscopic visualization. Subsequently, a microcatheter was advanced through the Fogarty and coil embolization was performed.  Gelfoam slurry was used between each coil pack.   The catheter was removed and repeat, post-embolization left renal venography performed to assess embolic effect.  Catheter and wire were then used to attempt cannulation of the right ovarian vein, however was unable to select this vein from the jugular approach.  The catheters and sheaths were removed and hemostasis achieved with compression.  The procedure was well-tolerated and the patient was discharged to the post-procedure care area in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Breast cancer. This patient had a right jugular port placed on [DATE]. When she presented to the infusion center, they could not find the port. Two-view chest x-ray showed the port had fallen into the soft tissues of the lower right anterolateral chest wall. She came today for port replacement and removal of the malpositioned port.   Procedure:  Right jugular single lumen chest port placement with imaging Removal of malpositioned right sided chest port  Findings:   1. The Right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses.  Needle entry was stored to PACS. 2. The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating in the right atrium.  3. The malpositioned port is identified in the anterior soft tissues of the right lower lateral chest wall. 4. Final image shows complete removal of the malpositioned port.    Impression:   Uneventful image guided placement of right internal jugular  power port catheter as described.  The malpositioned port was removed without incident.    Technique:  Image guided placement of right jugular single lumen chest port:   The right neck and chest wall region was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle. A PACS image was stored.  A 0.018" wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a 5 French transitional dilator. The smaller wire was exchanged for a 0.035" wire.  A peel-away sheath was placed at the venotomy.   The soft tissues caudal and lateral to the sheath entry site were anesthetized with lidocaine with epinephrine. A #15 blade was used to incise the skin.  Blunt and sharp dissection were used to create a subcutaneous pocket.  The pocket was irrigated with antibiotic solution.  A tunneling tool was brought from the pocket to the venotomy. The catheter was brought through the tunnel.  During suspended respiration, the catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy. The peel-away sheath was removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. The catheter was flushed, cut to length and attached to the port reservoir. The reservoir was aspirated, flushed, and heparinized per protocol.  It was sutured into the pocket using a single 2-0 Ethilon suture.  The pocket was closed using absorbable Vicryl suture and Dermabond and a running subcuticular stitch.  The venotomy was closed with Dermabond. A sterile dressing was applied. Attention was redirected to removal of the malpositioned port.  Removal of malpositioned right chest port:  The port reservoir was fluoroscopically identified. Local was injected into the scarred skin over the port reservoir. A #15 blade was used to incise the skin. The port reservoir was identified and grasped with a hemostat. The port reservoir and catheter were removed in their entirety. The pocket was irrigated and packed. Finally, 2 interrupted 3-0 absorbable Vicryl sutures were placed. Dermabond was placed on the skin. The site was sterilely dressed.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Myotonic dystrophy with gastroesophageal reflux. G-tube and J-tube dependent. The J-tube is completely clogged and leaking. Both were due for routine replacement on [DATE].  Procedure:   Gastrostomy tube contrast evaluation  and replacement   Jejunostomy tube evaluation and replacement/upsizing	    Findings:  1. The existing 18 French ballooned gastrostomy is adequately positioned. 2. The new gastrostomy tube is adequately positioned within the gastric lumen. 3. The jejunostomy tube enters the left lower quadrant and has its tip in a right lower quadrant jejunal loop. 4. The jejunal tube is completely clogged. A wire could not be passed. 5. The new 20 French jejunostomy tube was modified by shortening it 4 inches and adding 3 additional sideholes. 6. The jejunal tube has its tip in a right right lower quadrant jejunal loop.    Impression:   Uneventful image guided gastrostomy tube replacement as described above.  Difficult but successful replacement of a left lower quadrant jejunostomy tube. The tube was completely clogged. It was upsized to 20 French and modified by placing additional sideholes distally.  Procedure:  The anterior abdominal wall and existing gastric and jejunal catheters were prepped and draped in sterile fashion. A scout radiograph was obtained.  Gastrostomy tube:  Contrast was injected. The existing tube was removed over a Glidewire. A new 18 French gastrostomy tube was advanced over the glide. An 8 French long dilator was necessary to provide support enough to into the gastric lumen. The dilator and wire were removed and contrast injection showed appropriate position. The balloon was inflated with 10 mL sterile water.  Jejunostomy tube:  Attempts were made at passing several different wires through the completely occluded jejunal tube. Ultimately, it was cut and partially withdrawn. A stiff glide was advanced through the tube along with a 5 French angled catheter. The tube was removed over the wire and discarded. A new 20 French jejunostomy tube was modified by shortening/removal of the last 4 inches. 3 additional sideholes were created distally. It was then preloaded with a 5 French angled catheter and advanced over the wire. The balloon was inflated with 5 mL sterile water. Contrast injection confirmed placement.  The site was dressed.  The procedure was well-tolerated, and the patient was discharged from the angio suite in satisfactory condition. Real-time US images through the right axilla demonstrate appropriate percutaneous biopsy device placement.  Impression:   Technically successful US-guided biopsy of right axillary lymph node.  Treatment Plan:   1. Follow-up pathology results.  Technique:  Structure Name: 3 cm right axillary lymph node Imaging: Ultrasound Introducer: Yes Biopsy Device: 18 ga Biopince Sample size/number: 2.3 cm; x 3  Tract seal: N/A Cytology team: N/A  A superficial skin entry site was selected based on available imaging and the overlying skin entry site was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. Ultrasound images confirmed positioning. Core biopsies were obtained with the biopsy device. All devices were removed and hemostasis was achieved with manual compression. Tract sealant, if used, is listed above. A sterile dressing was applied. The patient tolerated the procedure and was sent to the recovery area for monitoring.
