Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Patient with acute myeloid leukemia requiring IV chemotherapy  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F double-lumen MedComp port (vertical)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French double lumen Medcomp power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with     Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESR[HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Staghorn calculus, here for PCNU for PCNL access.  Procedure:   1.	Right nephrostogram 2.	Unsuccessful attempted right percutaneous nephroureterostomy tube placement   Findings:   1.	Right nephrostogram: Staghorn calculus extending into the lower pole calyces. There is contrast filling the dilated to superior pole calyces and stenotic interpolar calyx. Contrast flows from the right superior pole calyx into the ureter.   Impression:   Unsuccessful attempt at right percutaneous nephroureterostomy tube placement.   Treatment Plan:  1. Chest radiograph post procedure (ordered). 2. Attempt will be made by urology team in the operating room.    Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written informed consent was obtained.  A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation.  The soft tissues overlying the access site were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Ultrasound was utilized to identify an appropriate access site. Static ultrasound image was obtained and stored to PACS for reference purposes. Subsequently, under fluoroscopic and real-time concurrent ultrasound guidance, access was obtained into a superior pole calyx infundibulum using a 21 ga needle. Contrast was injected for a right nephrostogram.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, 22-gauge Chiba needle was advanced into an inferior pole calyx until there was contact with the stone. Contrast was injected through the Chiba needle. A 0.018 inch (Nitrix) guidewire and then subsequently a 0.016 inch glidewire were attempted to be advanced through the Chiba needle and stones without success. This was repeated for a second stone-containing inferior pole calyx, again without success.  Attention was directed to the upper pole calyx. Less than 5 cc of air was injected through the initial 21-gauge access needle to determine posterior superior pole calyx. Under fluoroscopic guidance, a 22-gauge Chiba needle was advanced into the air-containing superior pole calyx. After confirmation with contrast injection, a 0.018 inch (Nitrix) guidewire and then subsequently a 0.016 inch glidewire were attempted to be advanced through the Chiba needle without success, given the acute angle of the access and the calyx.  Attention was directed to the contrast-containing interpolar calyx. Under fluoroscopic guidance, a 22-gauge Chiba needle was advanced into the interpolar calyx. After confirmation with contrast injection, a 0.018 inch (Nitrix) guidewire and then subsequently a 0.016 inch glidewire were attempted to be advanced through the Chiba needle without success given infundibular stenosis.  The needles were removed.   The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 66 years Male with past medical history of hypertension, atrial fibrillation, tobacco use, who presented in [DATE] with perimesencephalic subarachnoid hemorrhage. An angiogram at that time was negative. Patient now presents for 3-month diagnostic cerebral angiography    PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 45 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right internal carotid artery Right external carotid artery Left internal carotid artery Left external carotid artery Left vertebral artery  ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for the duration of the procedure as outlined above (Total intra service time, 45 minutes). Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Versed 1 mg IV Fentanyl 50 mcg IV Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter  5 French Vascade closure device Visipaque-270 contrast material (80 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the left internal carotid artery for better delineation of the underlying angioarchitecture. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a 5 French Vascade closure device  followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Cerebral angiogram November 20, 2023.  FINDINGS: RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. There is mild intracranial atherosclerotic disease at the cavernous and supraclinoid internal carotid artery segments.  RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No new aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. The previously seen medially directed outpouching just proximal to the ophthalmic segment is better seen on the 3-D angiogram below.  LEFT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the contralateral vertebral artery was achieved. The origin of PICA is normal bilaterally.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated a small medially directed outpouching just proximal to the takeoff of the left ophthalmic artery, seen on prior 3-D angiogram and stable in size, likely extradural.  COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: 1. No etiology for patient's previous perimesencephalic subarachnoid hemorrhage was identified on this angiogram. 2. There is a small medially directed outpouching of the internal carotid artery just proximal to the ophthalmic artery takeoff, previously thought to represent intracranial atherosclerotic disease, stable from prior. This lesion is also likely extradural.  Charles M Cawley, MD, was present for the key and critical portions of the procedure and associated imaging guidance.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  CVA with dysphagia  Procedure:   1.	Gastrostomy tube placement under fluoroscopic guidance.  Findings:   1.	The gastrostomy tube is in good position.  2.	Gentle hand injection of contrast material confirms positioning of the gastrostomy tube within the gastric lumen.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of 18 French MIC gastrostomy tube as above.  Treatment Plan:   The tube should be placed to gravity drainage and should not be used for 24 hours. 25 cc of water can be administered per hour. At 4 hours, if residuals are less than 30%, the patient can have tube feeds advanced starting at a half dose.   Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the mid abdomen were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.   Using fluoroscopic and ultrasonographic guidance, an appropriate puncture site was identified.  3 T-fasteners were placed adjacent to the planned tube access site. Positioning of the T-fasteners within the gastric lumen was confirmed by return of air and direct injection of contrast material.  Next, under fluoroscopic guidance, an 18-gauge needle was directed into the gastric lumen. Needle positioning within the gastric lumen was confirmed with aspiration of air as well as gentle hand injection of contrast material.  A wire was advance through the 18-gauge needle.  The 18-gauge needle was removed over a wire. Serial dilation was accomplished over the stiff wire. An 18 French Halyard G-tube was advanced over a wire in an antegrade fashion and advanced through the anterior abdominal wall. All wires and catheters were removed. The bulb was inflated with 10 mL of a 10% contrast mixture. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the gastric feeding tube within the gastric lumen. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained for reference purposes. The tube was flushed with saline. It was affixed to the anterior abdominal wall with a rubber flange. The patient tolerated the procedure well at time of procedure completion without complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Nash cirrhosis status post liver transplant. Presumed hepatorenal syndrome. Needs long-term HD.  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement 2.	Removal of non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter.   Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	Newly placed large bore central venous catheter tip terminates in the right atrium.  Impression:   1.	placement of a tunneled hemodialysis catheter   Catheter: 15.5-Fr., 19 cm (tip-to-cuff), tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.   Treatment Plan:   1. Routine catheter care. 2. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).   The skin and subcutaneous tissues overlying the vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a 21-g needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018-in wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018-in wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035-in Amplatz wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the dialysis catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   With the new access established. The pre-existing large bore central venous catheter was then removed. Hemostasis was achieved with manual compression and Dermabond.  The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  Patient tolerated the procedure well. The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 absorbable sutures.     Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with     Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Myotonic dystrophy with gastroesophageal reflux. G-tube and J-tube dependent. The J-tube is completely clogged and leaking. Both were due for routine replacement on [DATE].  Procedure:   Gastrostomy tube contrast evaluation  and replacement   Jejunostomy tube evaluation and replacement/upsizing	    Findings:  1. The existing 18 French ballooned gastrostomy is adequately positioned. 2. The new gastrostomy tube is adequately positioned within the gastric lumen. 3. The jejunostomy tube enters the left lower quadrant and has its tip in a right lower quadrant jejunal loop. 4. The jejunal tube is completely clogged. A wire could not be passed. 5. The new 20 French jejunostomy tube was modified by shortening it 4 inches and adding 3 additional sideholes. 6. The jejunal tube has its tip in a right right lower quadrant jejunal loop.    Impression:   Uneventful image guided gastrostomy tube replacement as described above.  Difficult but successful replacement of a left lower quadrant jejunostomy tube. The tube was completely clogged. It was upsized to 20 French and modified by placing additional sideholes distally.  Procedure:  The anterior abdominal wall and existing gastric and jejunal catheters were prepped and draped in sterile fashion. A scout radiograph was obtained.  Gastrostomy tube:  Contrast was injected. The existing tube was removed over a Glidewire. A new 18 French gastrostomy tube was advanced over the glide. An 8 French long dilator was necessary to provide support enough to into the gastric lumen. The dilator and wire were removed and contrast injection showed appropriate position. The balloon was inflated with 10 mL sterile water.  Jejunostomy tube:  Attempts were made at passing several different wires through the completely occluded jejunal tube. Ultimately, it was cut and partially withdrawn. A stiff glide was advanced through the tube along with a 5 French angled catheter. The tube was removed over the wire and discarded. A new 20 French jejunostomy tube was modified by shortening/removal of the last 4 inches. 3 additional sideholes were created distally. It was then preloaded with a 5 French angled catheter and advanced over the wire. The balloon was inflated with 5 mL sterile water. Contrast injection confirmed placement.  The site was dressed.  The procedure was well-tolerated, and the patient was discharged from the angio suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  ESRD  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the right atrium.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a  15.5 French, 19 cm (tip-to-cuff), tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   1. Routine catheter care. 2. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissues overlying the vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the dialysis catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Post transplant ascites. Potential narrowing at the caval anastomosis seen on MRI.  Procedure:   1.	US-guided right IJ venous access 2.	Hepatic and inferior vena cava venography with pressure measurements 3.	Right lower quadrant paracentesis.  Findings:    1.	Venography demonstrates patent hepatic venous anastomosis with no apparent stricture, and widely patient infrahepatic IVC, hepatic IVC, and cavoatrial junction.  2.	Pressure measurements suggesting portal hypertension, no significant venous stenosis:   Free hepatic vein: 18 mm Hg Wedged hepatic vein: 29 mm Hg HVPG:  11 mm Hg   Central hepatic vein (inferior to anastomosis): 18 mm Hg Cavo-atrial junction (superior to anastomosis): 14 mm Hg Right atrial: 12 mm Hg   Infrahepatic IVC: 21 mm Hg IVC just below anastomosis: 20 mm Hg Cavo-atrial junction (superior to anastomosis) (repeat measurement): 16 mm Hg   3. 3800mL dark brown tinged fluid removed from RLQ.  Albumen not giving.   Impression:   Successful venography and paracentesis as above.  Treatment Plan:   Per transplant team.  Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained.  The specific risks of bleeding, infection, pulmonary embolism, filter maldeployment, and filter migration were detailed and accepted. Written informed consent was obtained. The patient was assessed for conscious sedation and found to be an adequate candidate. A dedicated nurse monitored heart rate, blood pressure, and oxygen saturation throughout the procedure. Patient was brought to the procedure suite and a time out was performed prior to procedure initiation. The right neck and right lower quadrant was prepped and draped in sterile fashion.   Paracentesis: An appropriate access site in the right lower quadrant identified using ultrasound. The 5 French centesis catheter was advanced into the abdomen under direct ultrasound guidance, and connected to suction. After all free fluid was removed, the catheter was removed and a sterile dressing was applied.  Venography: The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the access site were infiltrated with lidocaine for local anesthetic. Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency. Under continuous ultrasound guidance, with permanent recording and reporting, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018" wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire. Through the micropuncture introducer set, an 0.035" wire was advanced into the IVC under fluoroscopic guidance. A 5 French sheath was placed at the access site. A multipurpose angled catheter was advanced into the hepatic veins and IVC and venography was performed, with pressure measurements as above.  All instruments and devices were removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. No immediate complication occurred, and the patient was discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by nurse present during the entire procedure. Patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]C.[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Breast cancer, malfunctioning port  Procedure:   1.	SVC venography through port catheter 2.	Fibrin stripping of port catheter from right groin access 3.  Completion IVC venography  Findings:   1. Left internal jugular chest port with tip overlying the superior cavoatrial junction.  Port and catheter tubing appear intact. 2.  Venography demonstrates a fibrin sheath along the catheter.  Port does not aspirate blood properly before stripping. 3.  Successful stripping of fibrin sheath.  Normal venographic appearance through port catheter after stripping. After stripping, port catheter aspirates and flushes normally.  Impression:   Successful fibrin stripping of chest port.   Treatment Plan:   If port malfunctions in the future, will require additional stripping or replacement.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).    The port was accessed with a Huber needle. Contrast was injected through the needle into the port reservoir and port catheter. Digital subtraction angiograms were obtained under fluoroscopy. Images were reviewed and saved in PACS.   The right groin was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. A micropuncture set was used to access the right common femoral vein under ultrasound guidance. Permanent ultrasound image was stored documenting needle entry. A 0.035 inch wire was advanced through the IVC into the SVC. A long 6 French sheath was advanced to the inferior cavoatrial junction. A 6 French 20 mm gooseneck snare was used to strip the port catheter. Venography after 3 strippings demonstrate near complete resolution of fibrin sheath. After 2 more strippings, venography demonstrated complete resolution of fibrin sheath. The port then was found to flush and aspirate normally.  The snare and sheath were removed from the right groin. Hemostasis was achieved with gentle manual compression. A sterile dressing was applied.  The access needle was removed from the port. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate postprocedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Multiple myeloma, port placement requested. Patient requested a left chest port due to a tattoo on her right chest.  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The left internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses.  2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating in the proximal right atrium.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled left internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the left internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 1% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the left internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency.  Under ultrasound guidance, the left internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the left chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the left chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position in the proximal right atrium. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 2-0 absorbable sutures.  Dermabond and Steri-Strips were used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with  Dermabond and Steri-Strips.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: Incidental right ophthalmic artery aneurysm  PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 30 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right internal carotid artery Left common carotid artery Left vertebral artery  ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for a total of 30 minutes (Total intra service time).  Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.035" Bentson guidewire 5 French Boston Scientific sheath 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter  5 French Simmons 3 glide catheter Mynx Closure Device Visipaque-270 contrast material (60 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the Cordis vert catheter in the right internal carotid artery for better delineation of the right ophthalmic artery aneurysm. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the Cordis vert catheter in the left common carotid artery for better delineation of the any possible aneurysms. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Mynx closure device followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Noninvasive imaging.  FINDINGS: RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a superiorly directed ophthalmic artery aneurysm better described on the 3-D angiogram below. There is no evidence of focal stenosis or early draining vein identified. There is mild fibromuscular dysplasia in the cervical right internal carotid artery.  LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified.  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally.   LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the  contralateral vertebral artery was achieved. The origin of PICA is normal bilaterally.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated a superiorly directed ophthalmic artery aneurysm measuring approximately 4.1 x 3.8 x 4.0 mm (transverse by dome to neck by neck). Distal to this aneurysm there is another aneurysmal dilation measuring approximately 2.4 x 0.7 x 3.6 mm (transverse by dome to neck by neck)..   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated no aneurysm or focal stenosis. Of note there is a fenestrated anterior communicating artery.   COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: 1. There is a superiorly directed right ophthalmic artery aneurysm measuring approximately 4.1 x 3.8 x 4.0 mm (transverse by dome to neck by neck) with a distal aneurysmal dilation measuring approximately 2.4 x 0.7 x 3.6 mm (transverse by dome to neck by neck)..  2. Mild fibromuscular dysplasia in the cervical right internal carotid artery.     Frank C Tong, MD, was present for the key and critical portions of the procedure and associated imaging guidance.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Multiple myeloma  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled central venous catheter placement       Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the tunneled catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a power-injectable, 5 Fr, 17 cm, tunneled non-cuffed central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.       Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care.  The catheter is ready for immediate use.        Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a peel-away sheath set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture peel-away sheath set, the wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Bilateral hydronephrosis, metastatic breast cancer  Procedure:   1.	Bilateral nephrostogram and nephrostomy tube placement      Findings:  Comparison is made to a previous exam dated CT Abdomen pelvix [DATE].  1.	Ultrasound demonstrates severe bilateral hydronephrosis.  2.	Nephrostograms demonstrate severe bilateral hydronephrosis. 3.	Successful placement of bilateral nephrostomy tubes.  Catheter(s):  8.5 F bilateral nephrostomy tubes  Impression:   Uneventful ultrasound and fluroscopic-guided placement of bilateral nephrostomy tubes as above.      Treatment Plan:   Patient should return for routine check and change in 8-12 weeks.     Technique:   LEFT PCN PLACEMENT: The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written informed consent was obtained.  A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation. The soft tissues overlying the access site were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Ultrasound was utilized to identify an appropriate access site. Static ultrasound image was obtained and stored to PACS for reference purposes. Subsequently, under fluoroscopic and real-time concurrent ultrasound guidance, access was obtained into a posterior, inferior calyx using a 21 ga needle and a triaxial sheath system ([VENDOR]). Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. A wire was advanced centrally. Serial dilation was accomplished over the wire. The wire and inner dilator were removed. Non-ionic contrast was injected into the collecting system and images of the antegrade pyelogram were obtained and stored to PACS. An 0.035” wire was advanced through the existing access. A nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.   RIGHT PCN PLACEMENT: The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written informed consent was obtained.  A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation. The soft tissues overlying the access site were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Ultrasound was utilized to identify an appropriate access site. Static ultrasound image was obtained and stored to PACS for reference purposes. Subsequently, under fluoroscopic and real-time concurrent ultrasound guidance, access was obtained into a posterior, inferior calyx using a 21 ga needle and a triaxial sheath system (Accustick). Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. A wire was advanced centrally. Serial dilation was accomplished over the wire. The wire and inner dilator were removed. Non-ionic contrast was injected into the collecting system and images of the antegrade pyelogram were obtained and stored to PACS. An 0.035” wire was advanced through the existing access. A nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.    The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  62 y.o. male w/ PMHx of well compensated Childs Pugh A cryptogenic cirrhosis presenting for evaluation of hepatocellular carcinoma.  The patient was undergoing imaging for evaluation of flank pain which demonstrated a liver mass.  He subsequently underwent an MRI performed in [DATE]. [DATE] MR abd – hepatic cirrhosis with splenomegaly and dilated main PV suggestive of portal HTN, 3.9 cm seg 7, 8 mm seg 4A – susp for HCC. Hypoenhancing lesions in seg 2, 3, 4A/B, 8 suggestive of regenerating nodules,MRI [DATE] shows progression of disease  Additional Clinical Information: Hepatocellular carcinoma with intrahepatic tumors  PROCEDURE:  Y90 Shunt study/mapping using MAA  1. US-guided left radial artery access. 2. Diagnostic visceral angiography 3. MAA delivery Cone-beam CT performed for intraprocedural localization, as detailed below.  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed, as follows:  Superior mesenteric artery: No replaced or accessory hepatic arterial supply. Celiac artery: Tumoral blush identified. Posterior branch of the right hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified. Proximal branch of the left hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified. Anterior branch of the right hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified.  Specific technical notes / catheter selection: None.  CBCT: Yes Catheter location:  - Posterior branch of the right hepatic artery - Proximal branch of the left hepatic artery - Anterior branch of the right hepatic artery Findings: Tumoral blush identified with supply from the target vessel.  Embolization: No Vessel embolized: N/a Coils used: N/a  MAA delivery performed from:  - 50% posterior branch of the right hepatic artery (series 21 image 1) - 25% proximal branch of the left hepatic artery, supplying the caudate lobe (series 29 image 1) cbct 6036 - 25% posterior branch of the right hepatic artery (series 39 image 1)  Future target Y90 delivery catheter position(s): Same as where MAA was delivered.CBCT 6036 caudate (25%), CBCT 6066 seg7(50%), CBCT 6066 seg 4a (25%) Treatment device: SIRTEX Split-Dose: .yes Dosimetry Model: MIRD dosed to the right lobe/segment. Desired lobar/tumoral (if partition) dose: 80-150 (unless split) Gy Additional details:     5cm seg7 LR5 (mr se7im11)  1.8cm caudate LR5 (mr se7im17) CBCT 6036 1.5cm seg4a/8 LR5 (mr se7im10) CBCT 6066 2.5cm seg8 LR4 (mr se7im14) CBCT 1.1cm seg4a/8 LR4 (mr se20im22) CBCT   IMPRESSION:   Successful Yttrium-90 SIRsphere selective internal radiotherapy mapping.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Patient will return in 2-4 weeks for Y90 radioembolization. 2. Access site precautions and orders placed.  TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and left radial artery patency and acceptable size criteria were documented and images were properly stored in PACS. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test B) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.   1% lidocaine solution was administered for local anesthesia. Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge micro needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5 mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started.   A 5-Fr Jacky/Sarah catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the visceral vessels described below. Angiograms were performed. A microcatheter system was used to catheterize distal visceral and hepatic vessels, as described below. Specific vessels catheterized and embolized are described in detail below. Tumor blush was confirmed on angiography.  Cone Beam CT (CBCT) was performed intraprocedurally for purposes of treatment planning, targeting and dose calculation. Axial and coronal images were created and 3D reconstruction was performed on a separate dedicated workstation under concurrent supervision.  After confirmation of target treatment vessel, 5 mCi of Tc-99 MAA was injected slowly in this location though the catheter.   All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A TR Band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis. The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to the Nuclear Medicine department for imaging. PLEASE PERFORM TWO SEPARATE DOSIMETRIES BASED ON SHUNT STUDY. 2. Right hepatic artery position (series 14) is distal to the cystic artery.  3. Will use TriNav catheter for delivery of right hepatic artery lobar dose  IMPRESSION:   Successful Yttrium-90 SIR-Spheres selective internal radiotherapy mapping.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Patient will return in 2-4 weeks for Y90 radioembolization. 2. Access site precautions and orders placed.  TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and left radial artery patency and acceptable size criteria were documented and images were properly stored in PACS. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test Type A) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.   1% lidocaine solution was administered for local anesthesia. Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge micro needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5 mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started.   A 5-Fr Sarah catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the visceral vessels described below. Angiograms were performed. A microcatheter system was used to catheterize distal visceral and hepatic vessels, as described below. Specific vessels catheterized and embolized are described in detail below. Tumor blush was confirmed on angiography.  Cone Beam CT (CBCT) was performed intraprocedurally for purposes of treatment planning, targeting and dose calculation. Axial and coronal images were created and 3D reconstruction was performed on a separate dedicated workstation under concurrent supervision.  After confirmation of target treatment vessel, 5 mCi of Tc-99 MAA was injected slowly in this location though the catheter.   All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A TR Band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis. The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to the Nuclear Medicine department for imaging. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled central venous catheter placement       Findings:   1.	The left internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the tunneled catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a power-injectable, 5 Fr, 33 cm, tunneled non-cuffed central venous catheter via the left internal jugular vein.       Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care.  The catheter is ready for immediate use.        Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the left internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the left internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the left internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a peel-away sheath set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture peel-away sheath set, the wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]C.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  HCC. Prior treatments with Y90 and microwave ablation. Persistent nodular residual disease on most recent MRI.  PROCEDURE:   1. US-guided right femoral artery access. 2. Diagnostic visceral angiography. 3. Transarterial chemoembolization segment 7 and segment 8 branches. 4. Transarterial bland embolization of the right phrenic artery. 5. Right common femoral artery angiogram and closure.  Cone-beam CT performed for intraprocedural localization, as detailed below.  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed, as follows:  Celiac artery: Conventional anatomy. Right hepatic artery: Extensive tumoral blush identified.  Posterior branch right hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified. Anterior branch right hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified.  Right phrenic artery: Vascular supply to the region of the previously treated tumor, without definite tumor blush.  Specific technical notes / catheter selection: 5 French sheath SOS2 catheter 2.4 Progreat microcatheter Fathom microwire  CBCT: Yes Catheter location: Right hepatic artery Findings: Tumoral blush identified with supply from the multiple branches of the anterior and posterior division.   Transcatheter embolization:  Tumor location: Segment 7/8  Embolic 1: Conventional TACE (50 mg doxorubicin in 5 mL contrast mixed 1:1 with lipiodol) for 10 mL total solution. Embolic 2: 2 vials 100-300 Embospheres  Phrenic artery embolization: Additional bland embolization of the right phrenic artery to substasis with 100-300 um embospheres.  IMPRESSION:   1. MAA shunt study aborted due to unfavorable multivascular supply to the tumor.  2. Successful conventional-TACE treatment of the segment 7/8 hepatocellular carcinoma.  3. Additional bland embolization to the right phrenic artery.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Patient will return to clinic in 6-8 weeks with abdominal MRI and labs.  2. Access site precautions and orders placed.  TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the groin was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The patient was placed on the table in a supine position. Following standard prepping and draping, the common femoral artery was punctured using a needle, and an .035 Bentson wire was advanced into the aorta. A 5-French vascular sheath was placed over the wire into the common femoral artery. A side flush was started.  A 5-Fr SOS2 catheter was advanced over an 0.035" Bentson wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the celiac artery. Angiograms and cone beam CT were performed and demonstrated multifocal vascular supply to the large segment 7/8 tumor, rendering the patient in unfavorable candidate. Additionally, cone beam CT showed favorable response to conventional chemotherapy performed along the superior margins of the tumor.   After conversation with the patient and his family, the decision was made to abandon MAA shunt study and pursue conventional TACE treatment. Consent was obtained from the patient's daughter, and doxorubicin was ordered from the pharmacy.  The above microwire/microcatheter system was used to catheterize distal the anterior and posterior divisions of the right hepatic artery, and chemoembolization was performed as detailed above. Follow-up contrasted and noncontrasted cone beam CTs confirmed successful treatment of the viable tumor, with minimal embolization of the normal hepatic parenchyma.  Attention was then turned to the phrenic artery, which previously demonstrated vascular supply to the superior aspects of the tumor. Phrenic artery was catheterized using a Mickelson. Repeat angiography today demonstrated vascular supply approaching the tumor, without definite tumoral blush. The decision was made to treat with bland embolization as detailed above.   A right common femoral artery angiogram was performed, demonstrating appropriate vascular access above the profunda femoris artery bifurcation. All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. Hemostasis was achieved using Perclose vascular closure device. The site was dressed in usual fashion.  The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by nurse present during the entire procedure. Patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]C[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  55 year-old female with untreated HCV and HPV-related Stage I cT2 N1 M0 SCC of the right palatine tonsil and ipsilateral lymph nodes in levels II-IV  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 2-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with a single subcuticular stitch and Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM AND ENDOVASCULAR PIPELINE EMBOLIZATION OF A RIGHT SUPERIOR HYPOPHYSEAL ARTERY ANEURYSM  CLINICAL INDICATION: 49-year-old female with a past medical history of tobacco use, hypertension, dyslipidemia who presented to [HOSPITAL] in [DATE] with high grade subarachnoid hemorrhage secondary to a ruptured basilar tip aneurysm for which he underwent WEB embolization. She is also noted to have unruptured right pericallosal artery aneurysm and superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm. She made a remarkable recovery following her subarachnoid hemorrhage. Given her young age, good health, and history of ruptured aneurysm, treatment of her other aneurysms was indicated. She underwent craniotomy and clip ligation of the pericallosal aneurysm [DATE] this past year. She returns today for pipeline embolization of the right superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm.  PROCEDURE:  1.	Cerebral angiogram  2.	Endovascular pipeline embolization   DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 2 hours.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. [HCW], PhD was the resident. Each actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS CATHETERIZED: Right internal carotid artery Right middle cerebral artery Left vertebral artery Left internal carotid artery  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right common femoral artery Right internal carotid artery Left vertebral artery Left internal carotid artery  VESSELS TREATED (in sequence): Right internal carotid  ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal anesthesia. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart.  MEDICATIONS:  Heparin 5000 units IV Ancef 2 grams IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 8 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 0.035" Bentson Guidewire 0.035" Terumo Glidewire (180 cm) 6 French 65 cm arrow  5 French Merit Performa Vertebral catheter 058 Navien guide catheter (115 cm) Phenom 27 microcatheter (150 cm) Asahi 018 microguidewire (200 cm) 3.25 mm x 12 mm pipeline embolization device 6 French Angio-Seal closure device Omnipaque-300 contrast (120 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, stent thrombosis/stenosis, stent migration, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, non-target embolization, puncture site hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed, written consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite, intubated, and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery. Through the dilator sheath, an angiogram of the of the right common femoral artery was obtained to ensure the arteriotomy was above the level of the bifurcation and the CFA was of sufficient size to use the 6 French Angio-Seal closure device. 6 French 65 cm arrow sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery, and under fluoroscopic guidance was advanced into the proximal descending aorta over the Bentson wire. 5000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement; additional boluses of heparin were administered at one-hour intervals. The ACT was checked to ensure that it was between 250-300.   The diagnostic catheter was used to select the right carotid artery. A roadmap angiogram right carotid artery was performed. The diagnostic catheter was advanced over the Terumo Glidewire into the right internal carotid artery. The arrow sheath was advanced over the diagnostic catheter into the right common carotid artery. Digital angiograms were performed centered over the head in the AP and lateral projections.  3D rotational angiography was performed with the selection catheter in the mid cervical segment of the right internal carotid artery to better delineate the right superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm and anatomy of the right intracranial ICA. The acquisition was processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.   The diagnostic catheter was removed from the arrow sheath and the 058 Navien guide catheter was advanced over the Terumo Glidewire into the distal cervical segment of the right internal carotid artery using roadmap angiogram fluoroscopic guidance. The Glidewire was withdrawn.   A working projection was obtained to best demonstrate the neck of the superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm, as well as, the distal and proximal landing zones for the stent. Superselective catheterization of the right middle cerebral artery was performed with the Phenom 27 microcatheter over the Asahi 18 microguidewire. The tip of the microguidewire was situated in the distal M1/proximal M2 of the right MCA. The microguidewire in the pipeline catheter was then exchanged for a 3.25 mm x 12 mm pipeline embolization device. The device was deployed under fluoroscopic guidance and a single shot X-ray was performed to confirm that the distal and proximal ends of the pipeline embolization device were in the right ICA communicating segment and right ICA cavernous segment, respectively. There was good apposition of the device along its entire course and therefore postprocessing of the pipeline embolization device was not required.  A final AP and Lateral angiogram were completed to evaluate the distal vasculature for perfusion deficits and emboli.   Using fluoroscopic guidance,  the additional arteries  listed above were selectively catheterized. Digital angiograms were performed in the AP and lateral projections centered over the head and neck.   After completion of the procedure, the sheath was removed and hemostasis obtained using the 6 French Angio-Seal closure device. A Tegaderm were then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram from outside institution from March of this past year.  FINDINGS: RIGHT COMMON FEMORAL ARTERY: Mild focal spasm of the proximal deep femoral artery related to access. The arteriotomy was above the level of the bifurcation and the CFA was of sufficient size to use the 6 French Angio-Seal closure device.   RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  There is a medially directed superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm, the dimensions of which are described on the 3-D angiography discussed below. Measurements of the ICA diameter were taken in very from 3.2 mm in the distal ophthalmic/proximal communicating segment to 2.8 mm in the cavernous segment. There is mild catheterization related vasospasm of the distal cervical ICA. The right middle meningeal artery originates from the distal cervical ICA.  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-PIPELINE EMBOLIZATION): The Pipeline device is well apposed to the vessel walls throughout it's course without endoleak. . Stasis of contrast is noted within the aneurysm. . Once again there is noted to be mild to moderate catheter related spasm of the right ICA without flow limitation. No perfusion deficits to suggest distal emboli are present.  LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a WEB device seen in the expected location. There is no filling of the previously seen basilar apex aneurysm. Reflux of contrast into the  contralateral vertebral artery was achieved. The origin of PICA is normal bilaterally.   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There are aneurysm clips seen in the expected location. There is no evidence of ongoing filling from the previously treated pericallosal aneurysm. No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified.     3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY: A 3D rotational angiogram of the  right internal carotid artery was completed and post-processed on an independent work station. 3D angiography revealed a superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm which measures 3.0 x 2.8 x 2.6 x 2.3 mm (axial by axial by neck-to-dome by neck). The internal carotid artery from the distal ophthalmic segment to the mid cavernous segment measures from 3.1 to 3.4 mm in diameter.    COMPLICATIONS: none immediate.  IMPRESSION:  1.	Successful placement of pipeline embolization device in the right ICA for treatment of unruptured superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm. 2.	Mild iatrogenic catheter related vasospasm of the right ICA stenosis 3.	No evidence of residual or recurrent basilar apex aneurysm or left pericallosal aneurysm. 4.	Independent origin of the right subclavian artery, remote from the origin of the right common carotid artery. Common origin of the right and left common carotid arteries, which did not require reverse curve catheter for catheterization.

DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 40 years Female with past medical history of heart failure, lupus, hypertension, COPD, with an incidental ACA aneurysm, status post balloon assisted coil embolization [DATE]. She now presents for follow-up diagnostic cerebral angiography.    PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 30 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow.   VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: None  ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for the duration of the procedure as outlined above (Total intra service time, 30 min ). Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 25 cc  Fentanyl 25 mcg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 5 French Simmons 3 Glide catheter   TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. We attempted to gain access to the right common femoral artery using ultrasound but were unable to despite several attempts. We did cannulate the common femoral vein using the microcatheter dilator, then removed the microcatheter dilator and held manual pressure for 10 minutes until adequate hemostasis was achieved. We then discussed with the patient different options done to proceed. Given the result of the aneurysm coiling during her treatment angiogram, we recommended that the patient first obtained an MRA time-of-flight time resolved. If that MRA were to show concern for recurrence, we could bring the patient back on a different date and attempt a transradial approach. The patient was agreeable to this plan and we aborted the procedure.  COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: 1. Aborted diagnostic cerebral angiogram due to difficulty obtaining access into the right common femoral artery which was limited by body habitus. Plan to obtain MRA time-of-flight time resolved in the meantime and consider a radial approach in the future.  Charles M Cawley, MD, was present for the key and critical portions of the procedure and associated imaging guidance.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Acute cholecystitis with cholecystostomy drain. No output from the drain.  Procedure:   1.	Fluoroscopic guided cholecystogram and cholecystostomy drain replacement  Findings:   1.	 Collapsed gallbladder body with filling of the proximal cystic duct there is no passage into the central cystic duct and into the common bile duct consistent with cystic duct occlusion. Perihepatic ascites.  Impression:   1.	 Technically successful image guided cholecystogram and replacement of cholecystostomy drain  Treatment Plan:   1. Drain to gravity drainage bag. Given collapsed gallbladder cavity, drainage may be minimal. Given perihepatic ascites, there may be leaking from around the drain skin site.  Technique:    The patient was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. The skin and underlying soft tissue was an exercise with 1% lidocaine. Contrast was injected through the existing cholecystostomy drain for a cholecystogram. An Amplatz wire was advanced through the existing drain and looped within the caudal gallbladder body. Upon removal of the existing drain over the guidewire, there was retraction of the tip of the Amplatz wire. An angled catheter was advanced over the wire, however the wire could not be removed through the catheter. The catheter and guidewire were removed together.   Using an angled catheter and Glidewire, the hepatic tract was catheterized and catheter advanced over the guidewire into the gallbladder body. Contrast was injected to confirm a stable position. Different guidewires (Amplatz) were used, however could not be adequately looped within the gallbladder body to advance a multipurpose drainage catheter. A Rosen guidewire was advanced into the gallbladder body, over which, an 8 French anchor drain (Malecot) was advanced. The anchor drain was locked within the gallbladder body and connected to gravity drainage bag and sutured to the skin with 2-0 Prolene suture. Contrast injection demonstrated appropriate positioning.   The patient tolerated the procedure without immediate consultation.
